english: Lyrics like these, delivered to a roots reggae rhythm and infused with dancehall vibes, somehow manage to hit home:
yoruba: Àwọn orin báwọ̀nyí, tí a kọ sí orí ìlú reggae àtijọ́ tí a fi àlùjó kún, ṣe kẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ̀rẹ̀ mi ìgboro:

english: Mother Nature yearns for life
yoruba: Ìyá Ìṣẹ̀dá ń kérora fún ìwàláàyè

english: The more the factories burn, she cries.
yoruba: Bí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ṣe ń ṣiṣẹ́, ìyá ń ké.

english: When will we learn, and be wise?
yoruba: Ìgbà wo ni a óò kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́, tí a ó fi gbọ́n?

english: The more the ice caps melt, the sea rise.
yoruba: Bí omi-dídì ilé ayé ṣe ń yọ́, òkun ń kún.

english: Despite the release of detained Reuters reporters, free speech remains under threat in Myanmar
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìdásílẹ̀ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn-in Reuters, ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ní òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ṣì jẹ́ ní Myanmar

english: Two Reuters journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo walked free from Insein prison in Yangon.
yoruba: Akọ̀ròyìn Reuters méjì Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo rìnrìn òmìnira lẹ́yìn tí a dá wọn sílẹ̀ ní ẹ̀wọ̀n Insein ní Yangon.

english: Photo and caption by Myo Min Soe / The Irrawaddy is a content partner of Global Voices.
yoruba: Àwòrán àti ọ̀rọ̀ abẹ́-àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Myo Min Soe / Irrawaddy náà ń bá Ohùn Àgbáyé ṣiṣẹ́ ìròyìn.

english: Media groups and human rights advocates are celebrating the release of Reuters journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo who spent more than 500 days in detention for their role in investigating the massacre of some Rohingya residents in northern Myanmar.
yoruba: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìn àti ajà-fún-ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn ń ṣe àjọyọ̀ọ ti ìdásílẹ̀ lẹ́wọ̀n-ọn akọ̀ròyìn Reuters Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo tí ó lò ju ọjọ́ 500 ní àtìmọ́lé fún ipa tí wọ́n kó nínú ìwádìí òfíntótó ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìpanípakúpa àwọn olùgbée Rohingya kan ní gúúsù Myanmar.

english: But despite their release, the state of free speech in the country is still undermined by the continued detention and persecution of some artists, journalists, and activists.
yoruba: Àmọ́ pẹ̀lú ìdásílẹ̀ tí wọ́n dá wọn sílẹ̀, ipò yẹpẹrẹ ni òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní ìlú náà nítorí wípé ìtìmọ́lé àti ìfìyàjẹ àwọn akọrin, akọ̀ròyìn, àti ajìjàǹgbara ṣì wà síbẹ̀ sẹpẹ́.

english: Consider the following cases:
yoruba: Ka àwọn ọ̀ràn ìsàlẹ̀ yìí síwájú:

english: Defamation case against The Irrawaddy
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀sùn Ìbanilórúkọjẹ́ kan Irrawaddy Náà

english: A defamation complaint was filed by the military's Yangon Region Command against The Irrawaddy's Burmese-language editor U Ye Ni over the news website's alleged unfair coverage of the armed clashes between government forces and the insurgent Arakan Army in Rakhine State.
yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ológun Agbègbè Yangon kọ ìwé ẹ̀sùn-un ìbanilórúkọjẹ́ sí olóòtú èdèe-Burmese U Ye Ni wípé ibùdó-ìtakùn-àgbáyé akọ̀ròyìn náà gbè lẹ́yìn ẹnìkan nínú ìròyìn ìkọlù láàárín-in ọmọ-ogun ìjọba àti àwọn adárúgúdù sílẹ̀ Ọmọ ogun Arakan ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Rakhine tí ó tẹ̀ jáde.

english: The Irrawaddy said it did nothing but report the escalating armed clashes in the region since the start of 2019.
yoruba: Irrawaddy Náà sọ wípé òun kò ṣe àṣemáṣe ju jíjábọ̀ọ ìwọ̀yáàjà tí ó bẹ́ sílẹ̀ ní sàkání náà láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ ọdún-un 2019.

english: Here is U Ye Ni’s response to the case filed by the military:
yoruba: Èsì tí U Ye Ni fún àwọn ọmọ ajagun rè é :

english: I feel sorry about the military’s misunderstanding of us.
yoruba: Ó ká mi lára nípé iṣẹ́ẹ wa kò yé ikọ̀ ajagun yékéyéké.

english: Journalism dictates that we reveal the suffering of people in a conflict area.
yoruba: Nínú ìmọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ iṣẹ́ ìkọ̀ròyìn ni ó ti fi lélẹ̀ wípé a gbọdọ̀ tànmọ́lẹ̀ sí ìjìyà àwọn ènìyàn ní ibi tí rògbòdìyàn bá wà.

english: Our intention behind the coverage is to push those concerned to solve the problems by understanding the sufferings of the people.
yoruba: Èròńgbà wa tí a fi tẹ̀lé ìròyìn náà ó ju láti fa àkíyèsí àwọn tí yóò tán ìṣòro sí ìjìyà àwọn ènìyàn.

english: The Irrawaddy is a content partner of Global Voices.
yoruba: Àjọṣepọ̀ tí ó dán mọ́nrán ń bẹ ní àárín-in Ohùn Àgbáyé àti Irrawaddy.

english: Jailed for satire
yoruba: Àjùsẹ́wọ̀n fún yẹ̀yẹ́

english: Meanwhile, five members of the Peacock Generation Thangyat troupe were sent to Insein prison to await trial for their satirical performance mocking the army. Thangyat is performance art similar to slam poetry featuring folk verses with traditional musical notes and is combined with song, dance, and chants.
yoruba: Ìyẹn bẹ́ẹ̀, àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ẹ ajótà Ìran Ọ̀kín Thangya márùn-ún di èrò ẹ̀wọ̀n tí ó wà ní Insein títí di ìgbà tí wọn yóò lọ sí ilé ẹjọ́ fún ẹ̀fẹ̀ tí wọ́n fi ológun ṣe. Eré ìtàgé tí ó ní àkójọpọ̀ orin abínibí, ijó àti ewì ni a mọ Thangyat mọ́.

english: The group was charged with violating article 505(a) of the penal code which criminalizes the circulation of statements, rumors, or reports with the intent to cause any military officer to disregard or fail in his duties.
yoruba: Ẹ̀gbẹ́ alájòótà yìí ti tasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin abala 505(a) tí ó ní wípé ọ̀daràn ni ẹni tí ó bá polongo ọ̀rọ̀, àyesọ, tàbí jábọ̀ irúu rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú èrò láti mú kí ikọ̀ ajagun ó máà ka ojúṣe rẹ̀ kún tàbí kùnà láti ṣe ojúṣee rẹ̀.

english: Zeyar Lwin, one of the accused, said:
yoruba: Ọ̀kan lára ẹni tí a fi ẹ̀sùn kàn, Zeyar Lwin, sọ pé:

english: All of our cases are political issues so that they need to resolve them as political issues.
yoruba: Gbogbo ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kàn wá jẹ́ ti òṣèlú torí ìdí èyí ó yẹ kí wọ́n ṣe àtúnṣe gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú.

english: And also, I’d like to say all of us need to join the work for amending the 2008 constitution being done in parliament.
yoruba: Bákan náà, mo máa sọ wípé gbogbo wa ní láti darapọ̀ mọ́ iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe sí ìwé òfin ọdún-un 2008 tí ó ń lọ lọ́wọ́ nínú ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba.

english: In my opinion all of these issues can be resolved if we can do the primary work of amending the constitution.
yoruba: Ní tèmi, gbogbo ọ̀ràn yìí pátá yóò jẹ́ yíyẹ̀ lulẹ̀ bí a bá le è ṣe iṣẹ́ àkọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀ ti àtúnṣe sí ìwé òfin.

english: Zeyar Lwin is referring to the 2008 constitution which many analysts believe was designed to reinforce military rule even after the restoration of civilian leadership.
yoruba: Zeyar Lwin ń tọ́ka sí ìwé òfin ọdún-un 2008 tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn atúnǹkanká gbàgbọ́ wípé a ṣe é to láti fi agbára fún ìṣèjọba ikọ̀ ajagun pàápàá lẹ́yìn tí alágbáda gba ìjọba.

english: Sickly filmmaker in detention
yoruba: Aya-eré-ìtàgé aláàárẹ̀ nínú àtìmọ́lé

english: The case of filmmaker Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi also reflects the restrictions imposed on critical artists.
yoruba: Ọ̀ràn aya-eré-ìtàgé Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi tún fi ìrísí ìhámọ́ tí a há àwọn akọrin pàtàkì mọ́.

english: A complaint filed by a military officer against the filmmaker's ‘defamatory’ Facebook posts led to his arrest.
yoruba: Ìwé ẹ̀sùn tí ọ̀físà jagunjagun kọ nípa àwọn àtẹ̀jáde ‘ìbanilórúkọjẹ́’ tí aya-eré-ìtàgé gbé sí orí Facebook tí ó fà á tí a fi fi òfin mú un.

english: Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi is the founder of the Myanmar Human Rights Human Dignity Film Festival and a known critic of the military's involvement in politics.
yoruba: Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi ni olùdásílẹ̀ iléeṣẹ́ Àjọ̀dún Eré Ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ Iyì Ọmọnìyàn àti ìlúmọ̀nánká alátakò ìlọ́wọ́sí ikọ̀ ajagun nínú òṣèlú.

english: His supporters are calling for his release on humanitarian grounds, since he has had half of his liver removed due to cancer and suffers from heart and kidney problems.
yoruba: Àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn-in rẹ̀ ń pè fún ìtúsílẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀ lóríi ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn, látàrí wípé a ti yọ àbọ̀ ẹ̀dọ rẹ̀ nítorí àrùn jẹjẹrẹ àti àrùn ọkàn àti ìṣòro kíndìnrín.

english: The Human Rights Film Network, a partnership of 40 human rights film festivals around the world, sent this letter to the government:
yoruba: Àjọṣe Eré Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn, tí ó jẹ́ àjọṣepọ̀ àjọ̀dún eré ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn 40 kárí ayé, fi lẹ́tà ṣọwọ́ sí ìjọba:

english: As a concerned international human rights community, we seek reassurance from the Myanmar government to ensure that Section66(d), which was meant to enhance progress of telecommunications, will not be used to silence the voice of Myanmarese civilians seeking to voice their opinions and take part in the democratic process in Myanmar.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹgbẹ́ ajìjàǹgbara àgbáyé tí ọ̀rán kàn, a tọrọ ìdánilójú ìjọba Myanmar láti ríi dájú wípé Abala 66 (d), tí ó yẹ kí ó sún ìtẹ̀síwájú ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá síwájú, tí kò ní jẹ́ lílò fún ìpalẹ̀mọ́ ọmọ ìlúu Myanmar tí ó fẹ́ sọ èròo ọkàn-an wọn àti lọ́wọ́ sí ètò ìṣèlú ìjọba àwa-arawa ní Myanmar.

english: The letter refers to the controversial Section 66(d) defamation law which has been used by authorities to charge critics, activists, and journalists.
yoruba: Lẹ́tà náà tọ́ka sí ti àríyànjiyàn Abala 66(d) tí ó sọ nípa òfin ìbánilórúkọjẹ́ tí àwọn aláṣẹ ń lò láti to fi ẹ̀sùn ìtakò, ìjìjàgbara, àti akọ̀ròyìn.

english: Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi's petition for bail was rejected by a local court. His next hearing is scheduled for May 9, 2019.
yoruba: Ilé ẹjọ́ ìbílẹ̀ kọ ìwé ẹ̀dùn tí Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi kọ fún béèlì. Ìgbẹ́jọ́ọ rẹ̀ tún di ọjọ́ 9, oṣù Èbìbì ọdún-un 2019.

english: “They should never have been jailed in the first place.”
yoruba: “Kò yẹ kí wọ́n di èrò ẹ̀wọ̀n ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀.”

english: Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo were sentenced to seven years in prison for violating the colonial-era Official Secrets Act.
yoruba: A rán Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo sí ẹ̀wọ̀n ọdún méje fún rírú òfin Ìkọ̀kọ̀ sáà-akónilẹ́rú.

english: The Supreme Court upheld their conviction last April with finality but they were released from prison after they were granted a presidential pardon during the country’s traditional New Year.
yoruba: Ilé Ẹjọ́ Àgbà di ìdálẹ́jọ́ tí wọ́n ṣe ní oṣù Igbe tí ó kọjá àmọ́ a dá wọn sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn ìdáríjì ààrẹ ní àsìkò Ọdún Tuntun ìbílẹ̀ orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

english: Groups like the Southeast Asian Press Alliance welcomed the release of Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo but they also highlighted the injustice suffered by the two reporters:
yoruba: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ bíi Southeast Asian Press Alliance kí Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo káàbọ̀ lẹ́yìn-in tí a dá wọn sílẹ̀ àmọ́ wọ́n sọ ìyànjẹ tí ó kojú àwọn akọ̀ròyìn méjèèjì:

english: They should never have been jailed in the first place, because they committed no crime.
yoruba: Kò yẹ kí wọ́n di èrò ẹ̀wọ̀n ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀, nítorí wọn kò jẹ̀bi ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kàn wọ́n.

english: While we welcome this positive development, the case of Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo is proof that journalists are in constant risk of political reprisal for keeping power in check.
yoruba: Nígbàtí a gba ìdàgbàsókè yìí wọlé, ẹjọ́ọ Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo jẹ́ ẹ̀rí wípé ẹ̀mí àwọn akọ̀ròyìn tí ó ń ṣe àyẹ̀wò sí ìṣèlú wà nínú ewu ìgbẹ̀san òṣèlú.

english: Brazilian indigenous people buy shares in railway company to denounce its failed environmental obligations
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ Brazili ra ìpín ìdókòòwò ní iléeṣẹ́ reluwé láti bá a wí fún ìkùnà ojúṣe àyíkáa rẹ̀

english: Indigenous peoples say the newly expanded railway impacted the area's wildlife and threatens their safety.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ sọ wípé iṣẹ́ tuntun fífẹ reluwé ń kóbá àwọn ẹranko agbègbè náà àti ààbòo wọn.

english: Image: Pedro Biava, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán: Pedro Biava, tí a fi àṣẹ lò.

english: On April 24, the shareholders’ meeting of Rumo Logística, a Brazilian railway consortium, had a few new, unexpected faces: a group of five indigenous people of Guarani and Tupi ethnicities who had recently bought six shares of the company.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 24 oṣù Igbe, ìpàdé akópìnín Rumo Logística, ìgbìmọ̀ reluwé orílẹ̀ èdèe Brazili, gba àwọn àlejò àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ tuntun: ẹgbẹ́ ẹlẹ́ni márùn-ún ìbílẹ̀ kan tí ó wá láti ẹ̀yà Guarani àti Tupi tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ra ìpín ìdókòwò mẹ́fà iléeṣẹ́ náà.

english: They each represent one of the five officially designated Indigenous Lands in the southeastern state of São Paulo that was affected by a 90-year-old cargo railway which Rumo operates and, in 2014, began to expand.
yoruba: Ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan wọ́n jẹ́ aṣojú Ilẹ̀ Ìbílẹ̀ tí ìjọba fọwọ́ sí ní gúúsù ìlà oòrùn ìpínlẹ̀ São Paulo tí reluwé akẹ́rù aláàdọ́run ọdún iléeṣẹ́ Rumo ń kó bá, ní ọdún-un 2014, bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í fẹ̀ sí i.

english: In order to compensate for the impact caused by the railway expansion, the state contractually obligates the company to "build new houses, prayer sites, a bridge, community gardens and acquire micro-tractors" for the communities.
yoruba: Láti san owóo gbà máà bínú fún ìbàjẹ́ tí ìmúgbòòrò sí i ilé iṣẹ́ náà kó bá agbègbèe náà, ìpínlẹ̀ ti fi ẹ̀tọ́ fún iiléeṣẹ́ reluwé náà láti "kọ́ ilé tuntun, ibùdó ìwúre, afárá, ọgbà àti ra ẹ̀rọ ìṣánko kékeré" fún àwọn agbègbè náà.

english: Around 5,000 people live across the five Indigenous Lands impacted by the railway's expansion.
yoruba: Ó tó bíi ẹgbẹ̀rún márùn-ún ènìyàn tí ó ń gbé jákèjádò Ilẹ̀ Ìbílẹ̀ tí fífẹ̀ reluwé kó bá.

english: But indigenous representatives say the company has failed to fulfill such duties, according to a story by Folha de São Paulo.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn aṣojú ìbílẹ̀ sọ wípé iléeṣẹ́ náà ti kùnà láti ṣe irú ẹ̀tọ́ náà, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ìròyìn láti ọwọ́ Folha de São Paulo.

english: The Federal Prosecutor's Office confirms this: 63 out of the 97 renovation works provided for in the concession contract are frozen.
yoruba: Ọ̀fíìsì Abánirojọ̀ Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ jẹ́rìí sí i èyí: 63 nínúu iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe 97 ìwé àdéhùn ìfìmọ̀ṣọ̀kan ti di àpatì.

english: On April 19, prosecutors recommended Ibama, Brazil's national environmental agency, to immediately suspend the new railway's construction as well as Rumo's operation license.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 19 oṣù Igbe, àwọn afẹ̀sùnkanni pa á láṣẹ fún Ibama, àjọ ètò àyíká orílẹ̀ èdè Brazili, láti ṣíra dá iṣẹ́ reluwé tuntun náà dúró, wọ́n sì gba ìwé àṣẹ Rumo.

english: They also recommended the agency to fine Rumo in 10 million reais (2,5 million US dollars).
yoruba: Bákan náà ni wọ́n tún gba àjọ náà níyànjú láti mú kí Rumo ó san owó ìtanràn mílíọ̀nù 10 owóo reais (ìyẹn mílíọ̀nù 2,5 owóo dọ́là orílẹ̀ èdèe US).

english: In a letter read at the April 24 assembly, the five indigenous shareholders detailed their plight.
yoruba: Nínúu lẹ́tà tí a kà níbi àpèjọ ọjọ́ 24 oṣù Igbe, àwọn aràpín-ìdókòòwò ìbílẹ̀ náà ṣàlàyé ẹ̀dùn-un ọkàn-an wọn.

english: They've described how the trains have affected wildlife in the area, as well as limited people's circulation.
yoruba: Wọ́n ti ṣe àlàyé ìjàmbá tí àwọn ọkọ̀ ojú irin náà ti fà fún ẹranko inú ìgbẹ́ tí ó wà ní agbègbè náà, àti dín àwọn ọmọ ènìyàn lọ́wọ́ láti fọ́n ká sí agbègbè.

english: In addition, they've reported their struggle in dialoguing with the Rumo, and also discredited the corporation's latest Annual Sustainability Report, which states Rumo it is "perfectly fulfilling their obligations, in a participatory and inclusive way, with the affected indigenous communities".
yoruba: Ní àfikún, wọ́n ti jábọ̀ akitiyan ìtàkùrọ̀sọ wọn pẹ̀lú Rumo, tí wọ́n sì bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu Àtẹ̀jáde Ìgbéró Ọlọ́dọọdún-un iléeṣẹ́ náà, tí ó sọ pé Rumo "ń ṣe ojúṣe rẹ̀ bí ó ti tọ́ àti bí ó ti ṣe yẹ, ní ọ̀nà tí ó fa àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ wọ inú iṣẹ́ ".

english: Speaking with reporter Pedro Biava of newspaper Brasil de Fato, Adriano Karai, of Guarani ethnicity, said the indigenous shareholders’ goal was simply to have their voices heard by the company's investors rather than profiting from the shares (which they bought for 17 reais each, around 4,30 US dollars).
yoruba: Nígbà tí ó ń bá Pedro Biava ajábọ̀-ìròyìn ìwé ìròyìn Brasil de Fato fọ̀rọ̀jomitoro, Adriano Karai, tí ó wà láti agbègbè Guarani, sọ wípé ìlépa àwọn alájọpín ìdókòòwò ìbílẹ̀ náà ni láti mú kí ohùn-un wọn ó dé etí ìgbọ́ àwọn olùdókòòwò iléeṣẹ́ náà dípòo kí wọn ó jèrè láti ara ìdókòòwò náà (èyí tí wọ́n ra ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan-an ní 17 owó reais, tí ó tó bíi 4,30 owóo dọ́là US).

english: Karai also described how the newly expanded railway has affected his community of Tenondé, located in the city of Paralheiros:
yoruba: Karai tún ṣe àpèjúwe bí iṣẹ́ẹ fífẹ reluwé tuntun náà ti ṣe kóbá agbègbèe rẹ̀ Tenondé, tí ó wà ní ìlúu Paralheiros:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: There is the noise of the train, which runs all night.
yoruba: Ariwo ọkọ̀ ojú irin náà, tí ó máa ń gbalẹ̀ kan títí lálẹ́.

english: The animals don't show up at hunting places anymore.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ẹranko kì í jẹ́ sí ibi ìdẹ mọ́ bíi tẹ́lẹ̀ .

english: We don’t have any quiet nights.
yoruba: A kò ní alẹ́ àìláriwo.

english: They also transport a lot of grains that end up spilling on the land, and we know that that food isn't of good quality, it is transgenic.
yoruba: Bákan náà ni wọ́n máa ń gbé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọkàn tí ó máa ń dànù káàkiri ilẹ̀, a sì mọ́ wípé oúnjẹ yẹn kì í ṣe ojúlówó, tí àtọwọ́dá ni.

english: Our lives are also in danger: the train passes through our territories, where walk visiting communities through trails.
yoruba: Ẹ̀mí àwa gan-an alára ń bẹ nínú ewu: ọkọ̀ ojú irin náà ń gba ilẹ̀ àjogúnbáa wa kọjá, níbi tí àwọn àpá ẹsẹ̀ àwọn àlejò afẹsẹ̀ rìn tọ́.

english: We are in constant danger of being hit by a train, because now there is one every ten minutes.”
yoruba: A wà nínú ewu ńlá ìjàmbá ikú ọkọ̀ ojú irin, nítorí ọkọ̀ ojú-irin ń pa ènìyàn nínúu ìṣẹ́jú mẹ́wàá mẹ́wàá báyìí.”

english: According to the Folha story, the indigenous communities initially proposed to Rumo that it outsourced the renovation works to a local committee run by the communities themselves.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ìròyìn Folha, ní àkọ́kọ́, àwọn agbègbè ìbílẹ̀ ti gbèrò pẹ̀lú Rumo wípé kí ó gbé iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe náà fún ìgbìmọ̀ tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ ìbílẹ̀.

english: According to the Prosecutor's Office, the company had initially agreed, but shortly after the October 2018 election of President Jair Bolsonaro, who ran on an explicitly anti-indigenous platform, it shifted its approach.
yoruba: Ní ti Ọ́fíìsì Abánirojọ̀, iléeṣẹ́ náà ti kọ́kọ́ gba àbá náà wọlé, ṣùgbọ́n ní kété tí ó di ẹ̀yìn-in ìbò oṣù Ọ̀wẹwẹ̀ ọdún-un 2018 tí ó gbé Ààrẹ Jair Bolsonaro tí kò fi bò wípé òun kórìíra ti ìbílẹ̀ sí orí àlèèfà, àyípadà dé bá ìpinnu ìgbésè ti ó wà nílẹ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀tẹ́lẹ́rí.

english: On November 20, Rumo suddenly canceled its participation at a meeting with the communities, and since then hasn't shown up at any other meetings.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 20 oṣù Belu, Rumo ṣàì dédé fagi lé ìkópa pẹ̀lú àwọn agbègbè ìbílẹ̀, tí kò ì tíì tún yọjú níbi ìpàdé láti ìgbà náà.

english: Speaking with Folha, the company said it never signed any agreement with the indigenous communities of outsourcing the renovation works to their committee.
yoruba: Nínú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ pẹ̀lú Folha, iléeṣẹ́ náà sọ wípé òun kò fi ìgbà kan t'ọwọ́ bọ ìwé àdéhùn pẹ̀lú àwọn agbègbè ìbílẹ̀ náà láti gbé iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe náà fún wọn ṣe.

english: The shareholders’ assembly on April 24 ended without any formal agreements, but Rumo's representatives said that the indigenous claims will be discussed at an internal meeting in May.
yoruba: Àpéjọ àwọn alájọpín ìdókòòwò tí ó wáyé lọ́jọ́ 24 oṣù Igbe wá sí òpin láì sí ìpinnu tí ó lórí, àmọ́ àwọn aṣojú Rumo sọ wípé ọ̀rọ̀ ti ìbílẹ̀ náà yóò jẹ́ sísọ nínú ìpàdé ti abẹ́nú tí yóò wáyé nínú oṣù Èbìbì.

english: Expansion works began in 2014. Around 5,000 indigenous peoples live in the area.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní 2014. Àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ tí ó ń gbé ní agbègbè náà tó bíi 5,000.

english: Image: Pedro Biava, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán: Pedro Biava, pẹ̀lú àṣẹ ni a fi lò ó.

english: Shareholder activism
yoruba: Ìjàgbara Alájọpín-ìdókòòwò

english: The Guarani and Tupi aren't the only ones engaging with so-called "shareholder activism", a practice that isn't very common in Brazil.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ Guarani àti Tupi nìkan kọ́ ni ó ṣe ohun tí a pè ní "ìjàgbara alájọpín- ìdókòòwò", tí ó jẹ́ ohun tuntun ní Brazil.

english: In 2010, the group Articulation of those Affected by Vale (Articulação dos Atingidos e Atingidas pela Vale) purchased the company's shares in order to sit at their assemblies.
yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2010, ẹgbẹ́ Ìmọ́rọ̀-yéni-yékéyéké àwọn tí ọ̀ràn-an Vale náà kàn (Articulação dos Atingidos e Atingidas pela Vale) ra ìpín ìdókòòwò iléeṣẹ́ náà láti lè bá wọn jókòó ní àjọ wọn.

english: Vale one of the largest mining corporations in the world, and the operator of the dam that ruptured in the city of Brumadinho in January 2019, killing 236 people (34 are still missing).
yoruba: Vale ni ọkàn lára iléeṣẹ́ awakùsà ní àgbáyé, òun sì ni ó ṣe àkóso ìdídò tí ó ba ìlúu Brumadinho jẹ́ nínú oṣùu Ṣẹẹrẹ ọdún-un 2019, tí ó mú ẹ̀mí èèyàn-an 236 lọ (tí 34 ṣì ti di ẹni àwátì).

english: On April 30, the day of a shareholders’ meeting, Articulation members pinned posters with the deceased people's names on the walls of Vale's headquarters, as reported by newspaper O Globo.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 30 oṣù Igbe, ọjọ́ ìpàdé alájọpín ìdókòòwò, àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ Ìmọ́rọ̀-yéni-yékéyéké lẹ ìwé-àlẹ̀mógiri tí a tẹ orúkọ àwọn tí ó ti re ọ̀run àrìnmabọ̀ mọ́ ara ògiri olú-ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ Vale, gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwé ìròyìn O Globo ti rò ó.

english: By voicing their concerns at those meetings, the companies are forced to register the activists’ demands in their minutes.
yoruba: Nítorí àìdéènà-pa-ẹnu ọ̀ràn tí ó kàn wọ́n gbọ̀ngbọ̀n nínú àwọn ìpàdé wọ̀nyẹn, ó di dandan kí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ náà ó kọ ohun tí àwọn ajìjàgbara náà ń fẹ́ sílẹ̀ nínú ìpàdée wọn.

english: One of the Articulation members, Carolina de Moura, herself a Vale shareholder, told O Globo:
yoruba: Obìnrin kan lára àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ Ìmọ́rọ̀-yéni-yékéyéké, Carolina de Moura, tí òun náà ní ìpín nínú ìdókòòwò Vale, sọ fún O Globo:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: We will keep speaking up.
yoruba: A kò ní dẹ́kun láti máa sọ ohun tí ó ń gbé wa lọ́kàn síta fún aráyé gbọ́.

english: The company must invest everything they make in improving our rivers and caring about human lives.
yoruba: Iléeṣẹ́ náà gbọdọ̀ lo èrè tí wọ́n bá rí fi tún àwọn odòo wa ṣe àti ṣíṣe àbójútó ẹ̀mí ọmọ ènìyàn.

english: Tanzanian authorities detain and deport Ugandan human rights leader
yoruba: Ìjọba Tanzania fi Ajìjàgbara Ọmọ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Uganda sí àtìmọ́lé, wọ́n sì lé e kúrò nílùú

english: Dr. Wairagala Wakabi [Image by CIPESA and used with permission]
yoruba: Dókítà Wairagala Wakabi [Àwòrán láti CIPESA tí a fi àṣẹ lò]

english: Wairagala Wakabi, a leading digital rights advocate from Uganda, was detained at Julius Nyerere International Airport in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania on April 25.
yoruba: Wairagala Wakabi, àgbà ọ̀jẹ̀ ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá tí ó wá láti Uganda, di ẹni àtìmọ́lé ní Pápákọ̀ òfuurufú Julius Nyerere International Airport ní Dar es Salaam, Tanzania lọ́jọ́ 25 oṣù Igbe.

english: Wakabi was invited to speak at the annual Tanzania Human Rights Defenders’ Day hosted by the Tanzania Human Rights Defenders Coalition (THRDC).
yoruba: A fi ìwé pe Wakabi kí ó wá á sọ̀rọ̀ níbi ètò Àyájọ́ Àwọn Olùgbèjà Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn ní Tanzania ọlọ́dọọdún tí Àgbáríjọ Olùgbèjà Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn ti Tanzania (THRDC) jẹ́ olùgbàlejò.

english: Wakabi is the Executive Director of the Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA), one of the foremost organizations working on internet policy and online free speech in Africa.
yoruba: Wakabi ni Olùdarí Àgbà Ìfọwọ́sowọ́pọ̀ Ètò-ìmúlò Ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ Gbogboògbò fún Ìlà-Oòrùn àti Gúúsù Ilẹ̀ Adúláwò (CIPESA), ọ̀kan gbòógì nínú ilé-iṣẹ́ tí ó ń ṣe ètò tí ó dá lórí ètò-ìmúlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára àti òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní orí ayélujára ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwò.

english: Wakabi was deported back to Uganda after several hours of interrogation, during which he was denied access to a lawyer.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wákàtí tí a fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá Wakabi lẹ́nu wò, tí wọn kò sì jẹ́ kí ó rí agbẹjọ́rò, a dá a padà sí Uganda.

english: Attorneys from the Tanzania Human Rights Defenders Coalition attempted to advocate on his behalf, but were told only that Wakabi was being deported on grounds of "national interest":
yoruba: Àwọn aṣojú láti Àgbáríjọ Olùgbèjà Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn gbìyànjú láti jà fún un, àmọ́ a sọ fún wọn wípé fún "àǹfààní ìlú" ni a fi dá Wakabi padà sí ìlúu rẹ̀:

english: Though the ordeal lasted only a few hours, it brought great consternation among rights advocates in the region, who have grown wary of Tanzania's treatment of activists and journalists.
yoruba: Bí ó ti lẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà kò ju wákàtí díẹ̀ lọ, ó mú ìjáyà ńlá bá àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ní agbègbè náà, tí ọ̀ràn ìwà àìtọ́ tí orílẹ̀-èdèe Tanzania ń wù sí àwọn ajìjàgbara àti oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ń peléke sí i.

english: In November last year, Angela Quintal and Muthoki Mumo both staff of Committee to Protect Journalists, were detained for several hours in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and had their passports temporarily seized.
yoruba: Nínú oṣù Belu ọdún tí ó ré kọjá, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Ìgbìmọ̀ tí ó ń Dáàbò bo Oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn, Angela Quintal àti Muthoki Mumo di ẹni àtìmọ́lé fún ọ̀pọ̀ wákàtí ní Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, tí ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnàa wọ́n di gbígbà lọ́wọ́ọ wọn.

english: Human Rights Watch asserted that Tanzania under the leadership President John Magufuli has witnessed "a marked decline in respect for free expression, association and assembly".
yoruba: Human Rights Watch sọ wípé lábẹ́ ìṣàkóso ìjọba Ààrẹ John Magufuli Tanzania ti rí "ìrésílẹ̀ ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ, ìkẹ́gbẹ́ àti àpéjọ dé ojú àmì".

english: In 2015, the United Republic of Tanzania promulgated the Cybercrimes Act.
yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2015, Orílẹ̀èdè Olómìnira Ìṣọ̀kan Tanzania kéde Ìgbésẹ̀ Ìrúfin Orí Ẹ̀rọ Ayélujára.

english: Within a year of the passing of that law, at least 14 Tanzanians were arrested and prosecuted under the law for insulting the president on social media.
yoruba: Ní àárín ọdún kan tí a kéde òfin yẹn, ó ti tó bí ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania 14 tí òfín ti mú tí a sì ti dálẹ́jọ́ lábẹ́ òfin fún pé wọ́n sọ̀rọ̀ mọ́ṣààsí sí ààrẹ lórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà.

english: March 2018 saw the passing of the Electronic and Postal Communications (Online Content) Regulations, making it mandatory for bloggers to register and pay roughly US $900 per year to publish online.
yoruba: Pẹ́pẹ́yẹ gbé ọmọ pọ̀n nínú oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà ọdún-un 2018 nígbàtí a gba Ìlànà Ẹ̀rọ Ayárabíàṣá (Ohun orí ayélujára) àti Ìtàkùrọ̀sọ Ìfìwéránṣẹ́ wọlé tí ó mú un ní túláàsì fún àwọn akọbúlọ́ọ̀gù láti fi orúkọ sílẹ̀ tí wọ́n á sì san owó orí tí ó tó bíi US $900 lọ́dún kí wọn ó tó lè gbé àtẹ̀jáde sí orí ayélujára.

english: This caused many independent blogs to go dark.
yoruba: Èyí mú kí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ búlọ́ọ̀gù aládàádúró ó wọ òkùnkùn.

english: The stifling of independent media through a mixture of sanctions against media outlets and legal threats against journalists has created an atmosphere of intimidation, self-censorship and fear of expressing alternative views about the country’s leaders.
yoruba: Ìpalẹ́numọ́ iléeṣẹ́ akọ̀ròyìn aládàádúró nípasẹ̀ àwọn àdàlù ìṣíwèé fún ilé iṣẹ́ akọ̀ròyìn àti ìrókẹ́kẹ́ mọ́ oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ti di ìdẹ́rùbà, ìkóra-ẹni-ní-ìjánu àti ìbẹ̀rù láti sọ èrò ọkàn ẹni nípa àwọn olórí orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

english: The detention and subsequent deportation of Wakabi back to Uganda appears to be a continuation of the Tanzania's government assault on free speech and dissent.
yoruba: Àtìmọ́lé àti ìdápadà Wakabi sí Uganda jẹ́ ìtẹ̀síwájú ìdojú-ìjà-kọ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ tòun èrò ọkàn ẹni ní Tanzania.

english: Digital journalist Luis Carlos Diaz is missing in Venezuela
yoruba: Oníròyìn Orí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà Luis Carlos Diaz di àwátì ní Venezuela

english: "Where is Luis Carlos?"
yoruba: "Níbo ni Luis Carlos wà?"

english: Image of the public online campaign shared by Provea.
yoruba: Àwòrán ìpolongo orí ayélujára tí Provea taari síta.

english: In the image they indicate the last time he had been contacted and the last time he tweeted.
yoruba: Wọ́n sọ ìgbà tí a pè é kẹ́yìn àti túwíìtì tí ó tẹ̀ kẹ́yìn nínú àwòrán náà.

english: On the evening of March 11, political commentator Naky Soto and wife of Venezuelan journalist and media activist Luis Carlos Diaz tweeted that he had been missing for five hours.
yoruba: Ní ìrọ̀lẹ́ ọjọ́ 11, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà olùfèsì sí ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú Naky Soto tí ó tún jẹ́ aya akọ̀ròyìn àti ajììjàǹgbara iṣẹ́ ìròyìn tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀ Venezuela, Luis Carlos Díaz túwíìtì pé òun ti ń wá ọkọ òun fún wákàtí márùn-ún.

english: [Update] The Union of Press Workers (in Spanish, the SNTP) reported that Luis Carlos had been detained by the Bolivarian Intelligence Forces (SEBIN):
yoruba: [Ìròyìn tí ó tẹ̀ wá lọ́wọ́] Àjọ àwọn Òṣìṣẹ́ Ìròyìn (SNTP lédè Spanish) jábọ̀ pé àwọn Agbófinró Ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́ Bolivaria (SEBIN) ti fi Luis Carlos sí àtìmọ́lé.

english: URGENT A Sebin commission confirms that journalist Luis Carlos Díaz has been detained by that police organism.
yoruba: PÀJÁWÌRÌ Àjọ Sebin kan fìdíi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé akọ̀ròyìn Luis Carlos Diaz ti wà ní àhámọ́ àwọn ọlọ́pàá yẹn.

english: They pointed their weapons at journalist [and members of the Press Union] Marco Ruiz, Luz Mely Reyes and Federico Black.
yoruba: Wọ́n yọ àwọn ohun ìjà ti akọ̀ròyìn Marco Ruiz, Luz Mely Rehes àti Federico Black [pẹ̀lú àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ òṣìṣẹ́ ìròyìn.

english: Hours before, Soto had tweeted that Luis Carlos Díaz had been missing for five hours:
yoruba: Wákàtí díẹ̀ sẹ́yìn, Soto túwíìtì pé àwọn ti ń wá Luis Carlos Díaz fún wákàtí márùn-ún:

english: @LuisCarlos is on his bike, but since 5:30 I've heard nothing from him and:
yoruba: @LuisCarlos wà ní orí kẹ̀kẹ́ẹ rẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n láti aago 5:30 ni mi kò ti gbúròó rẹ̀ mọ́, bẹ́ẹ̀:

english: – he's not at the radio station
yoruba: – Kò sí ní ilé iṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ náà

english: – he's not at home
yoruba: – Kò sí nílé

english: – he hasn't tweeted
yoruba: – Kò tíì túwíìtì

english: – he isn't answering calls
yoruba: – Kò gbé ìpèe rẹ̀

english: – he isn't answering SMS or WhatsApp messages
yoruba: – Kò fèsì sí àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ tàbí iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oríi WhatsApp

english: ‘Boca de Rua': The Brazilian newspaper produced entirely by people living on the street
yoruba: ‘Boca de Rua': Ìwé ìròyìn ilè brazil láti ọwọ́ àwọn ènìyàn tí ó ń gbé ní ojú òpópónà

english: After 19 years, Boca is still telling stories from the street
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ọdún 19, Boca ṣì ń ròyìn nípa àwọn olùgbé títì

english: Marcos Scher selling the paper at traffic lights before the pandemic. Photo: Charlotte Dafol/Used with permission
yoruba: Marcos Scher ń ta ìwé ìròyìn náà nínú ìdádúró iná adarí ọkọ̀ kí àjákálẹ́ àrùn ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀. Àwòrán: Charlotte Dafol/ a gba àṣẹ kí a tó lò ó

english: Nineteen years ago in Porto Alegre, in southern Brazil, a newspaper made entirely by people living on the streets was created.
yoruba: Ní ọdún mọ́kàndínlógún sẹ́yìn ní Porto Alegre, ní gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdè Brazil, ìwé ìròyìn kan tí àgbáríjọ àwọn tí wọn ń sun ìta àdúgbò ẹsẹ̀kùkú náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ ìròyìn títẹ̀ jáde.

english: Boca de Rua (Mouth of the Street, also known as Boca) newspaper was ideated by a group of journalists who wanted to provide this community with the tools to speak for themselves.
yoruba: Boca de Rua (Ẹnu Asùnta, tí a tún mọ̀ sí ìwé ìròyìn Boca) jẹ́ ọgbọ́n orí ọ̀wọ́ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn kan láti pèsè ọ̀nà tí àwọn asùnta àdúgbò yìí fi lè máa fi sọ̀rọ̀ fún ara wọn.

english: The project was conceived in 2000 and a year later, during the first meeting of the World Social Forum, the first edition of Boca was launched.
yoruba: Ní ọdún 2000 ni wọ́n bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ àkànṣe yìí, lẹ́yìn ọdún kan lásìkò ìpàdé àkọ́kọ́ Ẹgbẹ́ Àwùjọ Àgbáyé, ni wọ́n ṣe ìfilọ́lẹ̀ àkọ́kọ́já ewé rẹ̀.

english: Today, the newspaper is the only member of the International Network of Street Papers (INSP) created entirely by people living on the streets.
yoruba: Ní òní, ìwé ìròyìn yìí nìkan ni ó jẹ́ ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ Àwọn Ìwé Ìròyìn Ẹsẹ̀kùkú Àgbáyé (INSP) tí àwọn ẹni tí ó ń sùnta ń ṣe jáde.

english: The ideas for stories, interviewees and questions are all developed by the community itself.
yoruba: Àwọn asùnta wọ̀nyí tìkara wọn ni ó pilẹ̀ àwọn ọgbọ́n ìkọ̀tàn, ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò àti ti ìbéèrè.

english: Two journalists, who have been with the project since the beginning, are responsible for designing every new issue.
yoruba: Àwọn akọ̀rọ̀yìn méjì kan tí wọ́n ti ń tì kín àwọn asùnta wọ̀nyí lẹ́yìn láti ìgbà tí iṣẹ́ àkànṣe náà ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ni wọ́n máa ń ṣe gbogbo àwọn àtẹ̀jáde tuntun.

english: A group of volunteers also helps with support such as recording meetings, guiding the reporters about notetaking, and transcribing notes on the computer.
yoruba: Ọ̀wọ́ àwọn afínúfẹ́dọ̀ṣiṣẹ́ kan náà máa ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn nípa gbígba ohùn ìpàdé sílẹ̀, níní àwọn ajábọ̀ ìrọ̀yìn níran àwọn ohun tí ó ṣe kókó àti kíkọ ohùn tí a ká sílẹ̀ ní ọ̀rọ̀ sórí èrọ-ayárabíàṣá.

english: Published as a quarterly.
yoruba: Ìgbàdégbà oṣù mẹ́tamẹ́ta ni ìwé ìròyìn náà ń jẹ́ títẹ̀ jáde.

english: Boca's coverage ranges from reports of abuses suffered by those on the street to positive stories.
yoruba: Àwọn ibi tí Boca na ìyẹ́ dé bèrè lórí ìfìyàjẹ tàbí ìjìyà àwọn tí wọ́n wà ní àárín ojú pópó títí kan àwọn ìròyìn rere mìíràn.

english: Over a period of three months, the group decides on the direction of the coverage, they go out into the field, conduct interviews, take photographs and gather testimonies for the stories.
yoruba: Láàárin oṣù méta, òwọ́ yìí, pinnu àwon ohun tí wọn yóò kọ nípa rẹ̀, wọ́n jáde lọ sí oko ìwádìí, wọ́n fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá àwọn ènìyàn lẹ́nu wò, wọ́n ya àwòrán, wọ́n sì kó àwọn ẹ̀rí jọ fún àwọn ìròyìn wọn.

english: Member turnover is high, but on average, about 50 people work on each edition.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ jáde lọ́pọ̀ yanturu fún iṣẹ́ yìí, ó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ tó ènìyàn 50 tí wọn ń ṣiṣẹ́ lórí àtẹ̀jáde kọ̀ọ̀kan ní àpapọ̀ lórí ìwé ìròyìn ẹlẹ́ẹ̀mẹrin lọ́dún yìí.

english: After printing, each member of the group receives a share of copies to sell on the streets of Porto Alegre and all the proceeds go to the journalist/vendors.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n bá tẹ ìwé ìròyìn náà jáde tán, àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ yóò gbá ìpín láti lọ tà ní àárín àdúgbò Porto Alegre, tí èrè yóò sì lọ sí ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn/atàwé-ìròyìn.

english: The publication is also sustained by donations from supporters, many of them anonymous.
yoruba: Àtẹ̀jádè yìí tún máa ń rí ìgbọ̀wọ́ láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn olólùfẹ́ ìwé ìròyìn yìí, ọ̀pọ̀ nínú wọn ni kò fẹ́ kí orúkọ wọn ó di mímọ̀.

english: Rosina Duarte, one of the creators of Boca de Rua and the NGO ALICE (Free Agency for Information, Citizenship and Education), to which the newspaper is linked, said that the initial aim was “to give a voice to those who don't have one”.
yoruba: Rosina Duarte, ọ̀kan nínú àwọn tí wọ́n ń ṣẹ̀dá Boca de Rua àti Ilé-ṣẹ́ tí-kìí-ṣe-ti-ìjọba ALICE (Àjọ òfẹ́ fún ètò ìgbéròyìnsíta, ijọ́mọìlú àti ètò ẹ̀kọ́-ìwé) èyí tí ìwé ìròyìn yìí so mọ́ sọ pé ohun tí àwọ́n gbà lérò tẹ́lẹ̀ ni “láti fi ohùn fún àwọn tí ko ní ohùn”.

english: In time, however, they realized that this was presumptuous — the voices were always there, society just didn't listen to them, she says.
yoruba: Ó sọ wí pé, lẹ́yìn èyí ni àwọ́n ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ wá rí i pé ìlérò lásánlàsàn ni, nítorí kò sí ìgbà tí àwọn ènìyàn kì í fọhùn, àwùjọ ló kàn kọ̀ láti tẹ́tí sí wọn.

english: In a telephone interview with Global Voices, Rosina says:
yoruba: Nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú Ohùn Àgbáyé, Rosina sọ pé:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: When we arrived, we still had those pretty words which hold a lot of undertones of “nice prejudice”, as I call it, which is wanting to give something to them to help.
yoruba: Nígbà tí a bẹ̀rẹ̀, a maá ń lo àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tí ó lẹ́wà gan-an ni, èyí tí ó mú kí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn abẹ́lé ó maa  hu ìwà yíyin ẹni láìgba tẹni ọ̀hún” bi mo ṣe lè pè é nìyẹn, tí í ṣe ọ̀nà tí yóò jẹ́ ìrànlọ́wọ́ fún wọn.

english: But we realized that it was us who had to become literate in the language of the street.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a rí i pé àwa ni ó yẹ kí a di ọ̀mọ̀wẹ́ èdè àmúlò àwùjọ wọn.

english: They didn't have literacy in written language, but we were completely illiterate about life on the street.
yoruba: Wọn kò ní ìmọ̀-mọ̀-ọ́n-kọ mọ̀-ọ́n-kọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ ni àwa náà kò sì ní òye ìgbéayé àwọn tí wọ́n ń gbé ní títì rárá.

english: Catarina and Daniel wearing masks with Boca's logo | Photo: Luiz Abreu/Used with permission
yoruba: Catarina àti Daniel wọ aṣọ ìbomúbẹnu tí ó ní àmì ìdámọ̀ Boca lára | Àwòrán: Luiz Abreu / a gba àṣẹ kí a tó lò ó

english: The journalists’ original idea was to create a radio broadcast program using speakers installed on the city's lamp posts.
yoruba: Èrò àwọn akọ̀ròyìn yìí ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀pẹ̀pẹ̀ ni láti ṣe ìdásílẹ̀ ètò orí rédíò tí wọn yóò sì darí afẹ́fẹ́ ètò náà sórí àwọn gbohùngbohùn tí wọn yóò gbé sí orí àwọn òpó iná ẹ̀bà títì ní àárín ìgboro.

english: But when they contacted a group of homeless people, they were adamant: “We want a newspaper about us”.
yoruba: Ṣùgbón nígbà tí wọ́n bá ọ̀wọ́ àwọn ènìyàn kan tí wọn kò tilẹ̀ nílé lórí sọ̀rọ̀, wọ́n ranrí pé àwọn kò fẹ́, ariwo: “A fẹ́ ìwé ìròyìn tí yóò máa sọ nípa wa” ni wọ́n ń pa.

english: Rosina says the idea worried her at first, but it worked:
yoruba: Rosina sọ pé èrò yìí kọ́kọ́ kọ òun lóminú, ṣùgbọ́n ó padà bùṣe gàdà.

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: When they said they wanted a newspaper, we went after funding, still feeling our way in the dark, not knowing what to do.
yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n sọ pé àwọn fẹ́ ìwé ìròyìn, a bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní wá owó kiri, bí ó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé inú òkùnkùn ni a wà tí a kò sì mọ ohun tí a ó gbámú ṣe.

english: But one day the penny dropped: by telling what was happening on the streets, they were breaking news.
yoruba: Sùgbọ́n èyí padà dópin lọ́jọ́ kan: pẹ̀lú bí a ṣe ròyìn ohun tí ó ń lọ ní ojú pópó, wọ́n bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní gbé ìròyìn yìí kiri.

english: And if they became aware of this, the paper would organize itself very clearly.
yoruba: Bí wọ́n bá sì ti mọ̀ nípa rẹ̀, ọ̀nà à á gbà di lílà fúnra rẹ̀ nìyẹn.

english: Because we make news all the time.
yoruba: Ìdí ni pé gbogbo ìgbà ni a máa ń ṣiṣẹ́ lórí ìròyìn.

english: Some people do it in a more objective way, others less objective, but we do it.
yoruba: Àwọn kan ń ṣe é láì fi-igbá-kan-bọ-ìkan-nínú, àwọn kan kò sì náání òtítọ́, ṣùgbọ́n à ń ṣe é.

english: Over time, the newspaper also became a kind of social movement.
yoruba: Nígbà tí ó yá, ìwé ìròyìn yìí di ohun tí a lè pè ní ẹgbẹ́ àwùjọ.

english: The group meets weekly to discuss collective demands and possibilities for supporting the individual issues of its members.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ náà ń pàdé lọ́sọ̀ọ̀ọ̀sẹ̀ láti jíròrò lórí ìbèèrè fún ẹ̀tọ́ àti àwọn ọ̀nà tí wọ́n lè gbà ran àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ lọ́wọ́.

english: It is also linked to initiatives in the field, such as the Movimento Nacional da População de Rua (National Movement of People on the Street) and Amada Massa (Loving Dough), a bakery that aims to generate autonomy for people with a history on the streets in Porto Alegre.
yoruba: Wọ́n tilẹ̀ so pọ̀ mọ́ oríṣìíríṣìí ẹgbẹ́ bí i Movimento Nacional da População de Rua (Àgbáríjọ àwọn ènìyàn ojú u títì lórílẹ̀-èdè) àti Amada Massa (Loving Dough) ilé-iṣẹ́ adínkàrà tí èròǹgbà rẹ jé láti sọ àwọn tí wọ́n ti pẹ́ ní  àdúgbo esẹ̀kùkú Porto Alegre di òmìnira ara wọn.

english: Regarding the content of the stories told by the paper, Rosina recalls:
yoruba: Ní ìbàmu pẹ̀lú àkóónú ìwé ìròyìn náà, Rosina sọ pé:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: It seems like it's just suffering, it seems like it's just difficulty.
yoruba: Ó fara jọ ìyà ni kì í ṣe ìyà, ó fojú jọ ìṣòro ni kì í ṣe ìṣoro.

english: And it's not, we have discovered this joy, this resistance, we appreciate this immense, fantastic capacity to survive, not only to stay alive, but to keep hope, joy, affection and all these things alive.
yoruba: A ti ṣàwárí ayọ̀ yìí, ìtakò yìí, nínú rẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ ni a mọ rírì agbára dáradára tí kò jẹ́ kí ó kú, kì í ṣe pé ti àìkú rẹ̀ nìkan bíkò ṣe mímú ìrètí, ayọ̀ àti àwọn ohun mìíràn tí ó ti wà pẹ̀lú rẹ̀ wà láàyè.

english: Voices from the streets
yoruba: Ohùn láti àdúgbò ẹsẹ̀kùkú

english: In a telephone interview with Global Voices, Elisângela Escalante, who joined the group six years ago when she was on the streets, emphasized the importance of the newspaper in her life:
yoruba: Nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú Ohùn Àgbáyé, Elisângela Escalante, tí ó dara pọ̀ mọ́ ẹgbẹ́ náà ní ọdún mẹ́fà sẹ́yìn nígbà tí òun náà ń sun ìta tẹnumọ́ ipa tí ìwé ìròyìn náà ti kó nínú ayé òun.

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: A lot happened to me through the paper.
yoruba: Mẹ́wàá ṣẹlẹ̀ sí mi láti ara ìwé ìròyìn yìí.

english: It got me off the street.
yoruba: Òhun ni kò jẹ́ kí n sun ìta mọ́.

english: Because I lived on the street for three and a half years and I got out after a few months going to the paper.
yoruba: Ìdí ni pé ìta ni mò ń sùn fún odidi ọdún mẹ́ta àti ààbọ̀, mi ò sì sun ìta mọ́ lẹ́yin bí oṣù mélòó kan tí mo dara pọ̀ mọ́ ìwé ìròyìn yìí.

english: I was saving some money and started to rent my own space.
yoruba: Mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní fi owó pamọ́ láti gba ilé tí èmi náà yóò máa gbé.

english: Before I didn't earn my money, I depended on my partner for everything.
yoruba: Tẹ́lẹ̀, mi ò ní ọ̀nà ìpawówọlé kankan, ọkọ mi ni mo máa ń wojú rẹ̀ fún ohun gbogbo.

english: It makes a difference for me, I like to have my own money.
yoruba: Ó yí ayé mi padà torí èmi pẹ̀lú fẹ́ ní owó ti ara mi.

english: The cover of the edition which drew attention to the challenges of motherhood on the street.
yoruba: Ojúewé ìta ìtẹ̀jáde tí ó ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìpèníjà tí ó ń kojú àwọn ìyá tí ó ń gbé ní títì.

english: Photo: Agência ALICE/Boca de Rua, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán: Agência ALICE/Boca de Rua, a gba àṣẹ kí a tó lò ó.

english: Elisângela remembers one edition in particular, where the cover story asked: “Why can't we be mothers?”.
yoruba: Elisângela rántí ọ̀kan pàtó nínú àwọn àtẹ̀jáde ìgbàdégbà wọn èyí tí àkọ́lé òke rẹ̀ jẹ́: “Kí ló dé tí a ò le jẹ́ ìyá?

english: The report talked about the challenges that women with street backgrounds face in motherhood.
yoruba: Àtẹ̀jáde yìí sọ̀rọ̀ lórí ìṣòro tí àwọn obìnrin tí ó ń  tọ́ ọmọ ní ojú òpópónà ń kojú.

english: While producing the report, some women members of the newspaper managed to regain contact with their children who they hadn't seen in years, Elisângela says:
yoruba: Elisângela sọ pé: Nígbà tí a ń ṣe èyí lọ́wọ́ àwọn tí wọ́n jẹ́ ìyá nínú àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ gbìyànjú láti kàn sí àwọn ọmọ wọn tí wọn kò bá sọ̀rọ̀ láti àìmọye ọdún sẹ́yìn.

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: I think what we say [in the paper] is the truth.
yoruba: Mo lérò wí pé òtítọ́ ni ohun tí a sọ [ìyẹn nínú ìwé ìròyìn].

english: It's what we feel and what we experience within society.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ìrírí àti ohun tí à ń là kọjá ní àárín àwùjọ.

english: If it weren't for Boca, I wouldn't have any other way to do this and be heard by so many people.
yoruba: Bí kò bá sí Boca, kò bá tí sí ọ̀nà mìíràn tí n ó gbé èyí gbà tí ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn ó sì gbọ́ mi tó báyìí.

english: Through it I got a lot of things and I helped a lot of people too.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú rẹ̀ mo jẹ ọ̀pọ̀ àǹfààní, mo sì ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ fún ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn bákan náà.

english: For the first time in its history, the newspaper is unable to be sold on the streets due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
yoruba: Fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ nínú ìtan, ìwé ìròyìn yìí di èyí tí a kò le tà ní àárín àdúgbò látàrí àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn COVID-19.

english: In an effort to alleviate the effects on the reporters’ income, Boca de Rua has been transformed into a digital version.
yoruba: Nínú akitiyan láti ṣe ìgbésókè sí owó tí ó ń wọlé fún àwọn ajábọ̀ ìròyìn, Boca de Rua ti gbé aṣọ tuntun wọ̀, ó ti bọ́ sórí ẹ̀rọ ìgbàlódé fún kíkà lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára.

english: With a contribution of 20 BRL (around 3.75 US dollars) every three months, readers access the latest edition of Boca, as well as old editions and other material.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìdáwójọ iye òwó tí ó tó 20BRL owó ilẹ̀ Brazil (tí ó ń lọ bi 3.75 owó dọ́là ilẹ̀ America) ní osù mẹ́tamẹ́ta àwọn ọ̀nkàwé máa ń rí àyè ka àgbéjáde Boca tuntun náà, tí ó fi mọ́ ti tẹ́lẹ̀ àti àwọn nǹkan mìíran.

english: For the contributors and reporters, the most important thing is that the voices from the street continue to be heard during the pandemic.
yoruba: Ohun tí ó ṣe pàtàkì jù fún àwọn aládàásí àti àwọn ajábọ̀ ìròyìn ni pé ohùn àwọn tí ó fi títì ṣe ibùgbé ń di gbígbọ́ ketekete síbẹ̀ ní àsìkò àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn yìí.

english: When asked in a telephone conversation about his feelings about the newspaper, Marcos Sher, a 13-year veteran of Boca, said:
yoruba: Nínú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ nípa ohun tí ó rí sí ìwé ìròyìn náà, Marcos Sher, ọmọ ọdún 13 tí ó jẹ́ ògbóntarìgì Boca sọ báyìí pé:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: For me it's good, very good.
yoruba: Ní tèmi ó dára, ó dára gidi ni.

english: So you can see I'm not letting go, right?
yoruba: Ẹ̀yín náà rí i pé èmí náà kò gbé e tì, àbí irọ́ ni mo pa?

english: Sometimes I stop for a while, but I come back again.
yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn mo máa ń pa á tì, ṣùgbọ́n mà á tún bẹ̀rẹ̀ rẹ̀ padà níbi tí mo fi tì sí.

english: For me, the newspaper was a way to get out of [drug] trafficking and go back to work.
yoruba: Ní tèmi, ìwé ìròyìn yìí jẹ́ ọ̀nà láti bọ́ kúrò nínú oògùn olóró gbígbé ó sì dá mi padà sí ẹnu iṣẹ́.

english: It's good because it's something to do, to get me out of the house.
yoruba: Ó dára nítorí pé ènìyàn ń rí nǹkan ṣe tí ènìyàn bá kúrò nílé.

english: Having something to do is very important for me.
yoruba: Rírí nǹkan máa ṣe bí iṣẹ́ ṣe pàtàkì sími púpọ̀.

english: Editor's note: Talita Fernandes works with the newspaper Boca de Rua (Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul) and wrote a dissertation “Street, feminine noun: women in movement and the right to the body in the city”, by the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS).
yoruba: Ìfiyèsí olóòtú: Talita Fernandes ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìwé ìròyìn Boca de Rua (Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul) ó sì kọ àpilẹ̀kọ kan “Ojú títì, ọ̀rọ̀-orúkọ ti ìwà obìnrin: àwọn obìnrin nínú ìgbésẹ̀ àti ìjà-fún-ẹ̀tọ́ sí ti ara ní ìlú”, láti ọwọ́ Ifásitì Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS).

english: Kenyan Families suffer spillover effects from school closures
yoruba: Àwọn ìdílé l’órílẹ̀-èdè Kenya fi ara kááṣá látàrí ipa ìfọjọ́-kún ilé-ìwé tí ó wà ní títì pa

english: Kenya's 'out-of-school learning' curricula requires digital access that many lack
yoruba: Kenya tí pa ẹ̀kọ́-ìwé kíkọ́ tì, àlàkalè wọ́n báyìí nílò ìṣàmúlò ẹ̀rọ-ìgbàlódé tí ọ̀pọ̀ kò ní àǹfààní sí.

english: Editor's note: This post was co-written by Global Voices contributor Bonface Witaba and guest contributor Sri Ranjini Mei Hua, a researcher and writer from Singapore.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ Olóòtú: Àgbéjádè yìí jẹ́ àjùmọkọ aládàásí Ohùn Àgbááyé Bonface Witaba, aládàásí àlejò Sri Ranjini Mei Hua, aṣèwádìí àti òǹkọ̀wé láti Singapore.

english: In March, the Kenya government announced the suspension of schools as part of its measures to curb the spread of COVID–19.
yoruba: Ní oṣù Èrèlé, ìjọba ilẹ̀ Kenya kéde àfàró àwọn ilé-ìwé ilẹ̀ náà gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ọ̀nà láti dẹ́kun ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn COVID-19.

english: The announcement threw the school curriculum into disarray, affecting 18 million learners nationwide.
yoruba: Ìkéde yìí da àwọn àlàkálẹ̀ ẹ̀kọ́ ní àwọn ilé-iwé ilẹ̀ náà rú, léyìí tí ó ṣe àkóbá fún ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 18 àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jákèjádò orílẹ̀-èdè náà.

english: It also threatened to derail progress toward inclusive, equitable and quality education as described in Agenda 4 of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals.
yoruba: Ó gbégi dínà ìtẹ̀síwájú sísọ ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ di tọ́rọ́ fọ́n kálé, ìdọ́gba àti ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ tó mọ́nyánlórí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ó ṣe wà nínú Àgbéṣe 4 ti Ìgbéró Ìlépa Ìdàgbàsókè Àjọ Ìsọ̀kan Àgbáyé.

english: As part of efforts to ensure continued learning while protecting the health, safety, and well-being of learners and educators, the Ministry of Education, in collaboration with education partners and stakeholders, designed the Kenya Basic Education COVID-19 Emergency Response Plan, with the objective to promote “out-of-classroom learning” through radio, TV, e-cloud, and mobile phones.
yoruba: Lára àwọn ìgbìyànjú wọn láti rí i pé ẹ̀kọ́kíkọ́ ń tẹ̀síwájú bí wọ́n ṣe ń dáàbò bo ìlera, ìgbéláìléwu, àti ìgbáyégbádùn àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti olùkọ́, ni Ilé-iṣẹ́ Ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ ilẹ̀ náà pẹ̀lú àjọṣepọ̀ àwọn àjọ elétò ẹ̀kọ́ mìíràn ṣe ìdásílẹ̀ Àjọ elétò ẹ̀kọ́ ìpìlẹ̀, abetíwéré sí ìṣẹlẹ pàjáwìrì COVID-19 ti ilẹ̀ Kenya pẹ̀lú èròǹgbà láti mú ìdàgbàsókè bá ẹ̀kọ́ àtẹ̀yin yàrá ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kọ́ pẹ̀lú ìṣàmúlò ẹ̀rọ asọ̀rọ̀mágbèsì, amóhùnmáwòran, ìgbéṣẹ́ sórí àwọ̀-sánmà, àti àwọn ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ìléwọ́ alágbèéká.

english: Today, in spite of efforts by the Kenya Institute of Curriculum Development (KICD) to expand online content delivery, an estimated 80 percent of learners still do not have access to remote lessons, according to a study carried out by Usawa Agenda (an education network).
yoruba: Ní ọ̀ní, pẹ̀lú akitiyan Àjọ tí o ń mú ìdàgbàsókè bá àlàkalẹ̀ ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ ní ilẹ̀ Kenya (KICD) láti fẹ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá lójú sí i, ìdá 80 àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ni àwọn tí kò rí àǹfààní ẹ̀kọ orí afẹ́fẹ́ yìí jẹ síbẹ̀, gẹ́gẹ́ bí èsì ìwádìí tí Àgbéṣe Usawa gbé jáde (gbàgede ajẹmẹ́kọ̀ọ́ orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára).

english: This is due, in part, to unequal access to technology such as computers, laptops or smartphones, as well as prohibitive internet costs and unreliable internet access, especially for learners from disadvantaged families and marginalized communities.
yoruba: Èyí wáyé látàrí àìdógba oore-ọ̀fẹ́ sí ìlò irinṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ amúṣẹ́yá bí i ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá, ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àgbélétantẹ̀, tàbí àwọn èrọ̀-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ìléwọ́ ayárabíàṣá tí ó fi mọ́ ọ̀hángógó iye owó ìṣàmúlò èrọ ayélujára àti kùdìẹ̀kudiẹ nídìí ìṣàmúlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára pàápàá jùlọ fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ láti àwọn ìdílé tí wọn kò rí jájẹ àti àwọn ìlú tí wọn kò kàsí.

english: Even where the technology is available, there are concerns around young children’s unsupervised internet usage.
yoruba: Kódà níbi tí ẹ̀rọ ti wà lárọ̀ọ́wọ́tó gan-an, àìmáatọ́ àwọn ọmọ sọ́nà nídìí ìṣàmúlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára gan-an alára jẹ́ ohun tí ó ń kọ ènìyàn lóminú.

english: Prior to the lockdown, learners were able to access free meals at school.
yoruba: Kí ìtípa yìí tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní ooreọ̀fẹ́ sí ouńjẹ ọ̀fé ní ilé-ìwé.

english: Girls were able to access sanitary towels through an initiative to provide free sanitary towels.
yoruba: Àwọn omọdébìnrin inú wọn ní oore-ọ̀fẹ́ sí aṣọ ìlédìí ìsé-nǹkan-àlejò ti ètò kan fún ìpèsè àṣọ ìsé-nǹkan-àlejò.

english: However, with the prolonged shutdown, Education Cabinet Secretary George Magoha declared the school calendar as “lost,” meaning schools will remain closed until 2021, leaving thousands of students in a dire situation as their families are unable to afford food and basic necessities due to recent unemployment.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú bí ìtìpa yìí ṣe ti gùn sì, Akọ̀wé Ìgbìmọ̀ Ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ George Magoha ti kéde pé àwọn àlàkalè ilé-ìwé ti “bómi lọ”, tí ó túnmọ̀ sí wí pé àwọn ilé-ìwé yóò wà ní títìpa síbẹ̀ títí di ọdún 2021, léyìí tí yóò sọ ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ sí ipò òṣì pẹ̀lú bí àwọn ẹbí wọn kò ṣe lè pèsè ouńjẹ àti àwọn ohun èlò tí  ó ṣe kókó látàrí àìríṣẹ́ṣe ẹnu lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

english: In Kibra, for instance, an area deemed to be the largest informal settlement in Nairobi (and in Africa), most learners are unable to access KCID’s “out-of-classroom learning” curricula, and most do not have a place to study, much less play or exercise.
yoruba: Ní ìlú Kibra, fún àpẹẹrẹ, agbègbè tí wọ́n rí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ibi tí ìṣẹ́ àti ìyà sodo sí jùlọ ní Nairobi (àti ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀) ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ni wọn kò ní oore-ọ̀fẹ́ sí àlàkalẹ̀ ẹ̀kọ́ àtẹ̀yìn yàrá ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kọ́ àjọ KCID, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni ọ̀pọ̀ kò tilẹ̀ ní ibi tí wọn ó ti kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ áḿbèlètàsé ibi eré ìdarayá.

english: (For many years, the area was called “Kibera,” a mispronunciation of the word kibra, a Nubian word for “forest.” Kenya's Nubian community feels using “Kibera” robs them of their identity).
yoruba: (Láti ọ̀pọ̀ ọdún séyìn, agbègbè yìí ti ń jẹ́ pípẹ̀ ní “Kibera” tí í ṣe àṣìpè Kibra tí ó túmọ̀ sí “igbó kìjikìji” ní èdè Nubia. Fífi ọmọ peni lérú ni àwọn ará agbègbè Nubia ní Kenya máa ń rí lílo “Kibera” sí)

english: In a Skype interview with Asha Jaffar, a journalist residing in Kibra who covers stories about the plight of the Kibra community, Jaffar told Global Voices that there were a limited number of free libraries that allowed up to 10 learners at a time to do their homework.
yoruba: Nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò lórí Skype pẹ̀lú Asha Jaffar, akọ̀rọ̀yìn tí ó ń gbé ní Kibra, ẹni tí ó gbé ìròyìn nípa ewu tí ó wu àwọn agbègbè Kibra, Jaffar sọ fún Ohùn Àgbáyé pé  àwọn yàrá ìkàwé lọ́fẹ̀ẹ́ tí ó lè gba àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ mẹ́wàá ní ẹ̀ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo kò tó nǹkan.

english: However, these learners are required to give up the space to the next lot of learners after about an hour.
yoruba: Àmọ́, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wọ̀nyí ní láti máa fi àyè wọn sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn bíi wákàtí kan kí ọ̀wọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ mìíràn lè ṣàmúlò àwọn àyè náà.

english: She added that free tuition initiatives for learners have had to scale down due to social distancing rules imposed by the government and health officials.
yoruba: Ó fi kún un pé iná ètò fún owó ilé-ìwé ọ̀fẹ́ fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní láti jó rẹ̀yìn nítorí òfin jíjìnnà síraẹni láwùjọ tí ìjọba àti àwọn ikọ̀ elétò ìlera kàn nípá.

english: Asha Jaffar, a journalist and Kibra resident, points over Kibra settlement.
yoruba: Asha Jaffar, akọ̀rọ̀yìn àti olùgbé Kibra ń nawọ́ sí àwọn ibùgbé Kibra.

english: Photo by Kibra Food Drive, August 2020, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti Ètò ìpèsè Ouńjẹ ọ̀fé Kibra, Oṣù Ògún, ọdún 2020,  àwòrán jẹ́ lílò pẹ̀lú ìyọ̀nda.

english: The long-term impact of school closures are wide-ranging and even more devastating to families living below the poverty line.
yoruba: Ipa ìtìpa ọlọ́jọ́ gbọọrọ àwọn ilé-ìwé náà ti ń kọjá agbára bẹ́ẹ̀ ni ó sì ń lapa burúkú lórí àwọn ìdílé tí wọn kò rọ́wọ́ họrí.

english: As food security takes precedence over education, learners — particularly girls and young women — from vulnerable families often have to work on farms and contribute to household chores or care work instead of learning.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú bí aáyan àtijẹ-àtimu ṣe borí aáyan ètò- ẹ̀kọ́, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ pàápàá àwọn omọdébìnrin àti àwọn abilékọ kékèké láti àwọn ìdílé tí ìṣẹ́ ń bá fínra nílò láti ṣe iṣẹ́ oko dídá àti àwọn iṣẹ́ ilé tàbí iṣẹ́ àgbàtọ́ dípò ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé kíkọ́.

english: This played out during the lockdown which coincided with the peak planting season in March.
yoruba: Èyí wáyé nínú ìtìpa yìí tí ó ṣe déédé pẹ̀lú àkókò tí ọ̀gbìn ṣíṣe wọ́pọ̀ jùlọ ní oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà.

english: Some girls may even be subject to early marriage which puts them at a higher risk of dropping out of school, often as a result of early pregnancies.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọdébìnrin mìíràn gan-an lè tibẹ̀ ti kékeré lọ́kọ léyìí tí yóò sọ wọ́n sínú ewu pípa ilé-ìwé tì láti ara oyún àpàpàndodo.

english: Hence, educational outcomes for the most vulnerable families will suffer as they have little reason to send their children back to school when it reopens.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ nínú àwọn ìdílé tí ìṣẹ́ ń bá fínra yóò lami, ìdí ni pé ọ̀pọ̀ nínú wọn ni kò rí ìdí pàtàkì tí ó fi yẹ kí wọn ó darí àwọn ọmọ wọn padà sí ilé-ìwé tí àwọn ilé-ìwé bá di ṣísí padà.

english: In  March, Jaffar launched Kibra Food Drive to help alleviate hunger in the Kibra community through donations of food parcels to the most vulnerable families.
yoruba: Ní oṣù Ẹrénà, Jaffar ṣe ìfilọ́lẹ̀ Ìpèsè Ouńjẹ ọ̀fé Kibra, láti lé ebi jìnà sí agbègbè Kibra pẹ̀lú fífi àpọ̀ kékèké tí ó kún fún oríṣìíríṣìí oúnjẹ ta àwọn ìdílé kòlàkòṣagbe lọ́ọrẹ.

english: It started through donation solicitation via M-Pesa (a mobile wallet), with the aim of feeding 100 vulnerable families a week, but with an increasing need for support, the initiative has fed 2,400 families, as of August 5.
yoruba: Ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú wíwá àwọn ìtọrẹ àánú lórí M-pesa (àpò owó orí èrọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèéká) pẹ̀lú èrọ̀ngbà láti bọ́ àwọn ìdílé tí kò ń ọ̀pọ́n pọ́n là 100 fún ọ̀ṣẹ̀ kan, ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú bí àwọn tí wọ́n nílò ìrànlọ́wọ́ ṣe ń pọ̀ si, ètò yìí ti bọ́ ìdílé tí ó tó 2400 títí di Ọjọ 5, Oṣù Ògún.

english: Jaffar recognizes that providing free meals is not enough because the families ultimately need support to start small businesses.
yoruba: Jaffar rí i mọ̀ pé ìpèsè oúnjẹ ọ̀fẹ́ kò tó nítorí pé àwọn ìdílé yìí nílò àtìlẹ́yìn láti bẹ̀rẹ̀ oko-òwò kéékèèké.

english: However, the community remains in a deadlock as trade and economic activity stalls.
yoruba: Àmọ́ ṣá o, orọ̀ ajé agbègbè yìí dùró gbọhin pẹ̀lú bí káràkátà ṣe ti wara ro.

english: A volunteer delivers food to Kibra residents through the Kibra food drive in Kibra, Kenya, August 2020.
yoruba: Afínúfẹ́dọ̀ pín oúnjẹ fún àwọn ènìyàn ibùgbé Kibra láti Ètò ìpèsè Ouńjẹ ọ̀fé Kibra, Kenya, Oṣù Ògún, ọdún 2020.

english: Photo by Kibra Food Drive, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti Ètò ìpèsè Ouńjẹ ọ̀fé Kibra, àwòrán jẹ́ lílò pẹ̀lú ìyọ̀nda.

english: Kenya anticipates a new academic year in 2021 — but this all depends on the number of COVID-19 infections — according to Education Cabinet Secretary Magoha.
yoruba: Kenya ń retí ọdún ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ tuntun nì ọdún 2021— Ṣùgbọ́n èyí tún wà lọ́wọ́ iye ènìyàn tí àrùn COVID-19 bá kọlù —  gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀rọ̀ Magoha, Akọ̀wé Ìgbìmọ̀ Ètò-ẹ̀kọ́.

english: Several education experts say that this period is an opportune time for the government to conduct a gap analysis of the education system and perform a complete reboot in the quest to provide equitable access to learning for all as envisioned in the Kenya Basic Education COVID-19 Emergency Response Plan.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn amòye nídìí ètò ẹ̀kọ́ sọ báyìí pé àkókò yìí jé oore-ọ̀fẹ́ fún ìjọba láti ṣe ìgbéléwọ̀n ètò-ẹ̀kọ́, kí wọn ó sì tún iná ìpèsè ẹ̀kọ́ fún tẹ̀rútọmọ dá gẹ́gẹ́ bí àfojúsùn àjọ elétò ẹ̀kọ́ ìpìlẹ, abetíwéré sí ìṣẹ̀lè pàjáwìrì COVID-19 ti ilẹ̀ Kenya.

english: The first step would be to allocate budget toward improving the school infrastructure in terms of lighting, desks and chairs and providing reliable electricity supply — especially in rural areas.
yoruba: Ìgbésẹ̀ àkọ́kọ́, yóò jẹ́ ìya owó sọ́tọ̀ láti mú ìdàgbàsókè bá ilé-ìwé nípa ìpèsè iná, àwọn tábìlì ìkàwé, àga ìjókòó àti iná mọ̀nàmọ́ná tó ṣeé fọkàn tán, pàápàá jùlọ ní àwọn ìgbèríko.

english: Next, the government could lower water and electricity tariffs for schools as these huge costs are hurting their operations.
yoruba: Léyìn èyí, ìjọba lè mú àdínkù bá owó iná àti owó omi ní àwọn ilé ìwé nítorí pé bí ó ṣe gbérí yìí ń pa iṣẹ́ wọn lára.

english: Only when these priorities are sorted can efforts resume on a stalled digital literacy project initiated in 2013 by the government.
yoruba: Léyin bí àwọn ohun tí ó ṣe kókó wọ̀nyí bá ti di yíyanjú nìkan ni ìgbìyànjú le bẹ̀rẹ̀ lórí Iṣẹ́ àkànṣe ìkàwé ìgbàlódé alápilẹ̀rọ tí ìjọba gbé jáde ni ọdún 2013.

english: The digital literacy program aimed to ensure that learners in lower primary school (grades 1-3) can use digital technology and communication tools, with an overarching objective to transform learning in Kenya into a 21st-century education system.
yoruba: Ètò Mọ̀ọ́kọ-mọ̀ọ́kà Ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá yìí gbèrò láti rí i wí pé àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ilé-ìwé alákọ̀ọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀ (onípò 1-3) lè lo àwọn èrọ ìgbàlódé àti àwọn ohun èlò ìbáraẹnisọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú èròǹgbà láti mú kí ètò ẹ̀kọ́ ilẹ̀ Kenya ó bá ti ọgọ́rùn-ún ọdún 21 mu.

english: The project stalled barely got off the ground after its pilot phase due to failure to meet intended outcomes and educators being ill-prepared to scale out the initiative.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ àkànṣe náà fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ má gbéra sọ bí wọ́n ṣe kọ́kọ́ múra sí i tó pẹ̀lú bí àwọn àfojúsùn wọn ṣe kùnà àti bí ìmúrasílẹ̀ àwọn olùkọ́ ṣe mẹ́hẹ.

english: To achieve success, the program requires extensive ICT training for educators so they can effectively use and troubleshoot these gadgets.
yoruba: Láti le kẹ́sẹ járí, ètò yìí nílò kí wọn ó dá àwọn olùkọ́ lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìlò àwọn ẹ̀rọ ìgbàlódé kí wọn ó bà lè ṣàmúlò àwọn ẹ̀rọ náà bí ó ti yẹ.

english: Kenya has progressed from a Universal Primary Education (UPE) agenda into an Education For All (EFA) agenda.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ́n Orílẹ̀-èdè Kenya ti sún láti ìṣètò Ẹ̀kọ́ alákọ̀ọ́bẹ̀ẹ̀rẹ̀ káàkiri àgbáyé (UPE) sí àgbéṣe Ẹ̀kọ́-ìwé fún gbogbo ènìyàn (EFA).

english: UPE, the second goal in the United Nations Millennium Development Goal, aimed to ensure that by 2015, all children around the world completed primary schooling, whereas EFA, was a global movement led by UNESCO, aimed to bring the benefits of education to “every citizen in every society.”
yoruba: UPE tí ó jẹ́ Ìlépa kejì Ilépa ìdàgbàsókè ti Ẹgbẹ̀rún ọdún Àjọ Ìsọ̀kan Àgbáyé tí ó gbèrò láti rí i wí pé nígbà tí ó bá fi máa di ọdún 2015, gbogbo ọmọ ní jákèjádò àgbáyé ni wọn ó ti parí ilé-ìwé alákòóbẹ̀ẹ̀rẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n EFA ní tirẹ̀ jẹ́ ìpolongo àgbáyé tí àjọ UNESCO léwájú rẹ̀, pẹ̀lú èròǹgbà láti mú àǹfààní ẹ̀kọ́-ìwé tọ “gbogbo ọmọ ìlú ní gbogbo àwọn àwùjọ ”  àgbáyé lọ.

english: With these gains, Kenya cannot afford to roll back on progress.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú àwọn àǹfààní wọ̀nyí, orílẹ̀-èdè Kenya ò gbọdọ̀ fa ọwọ́ aago ìdàgbàsókè yìí sẹ́yìn.

english: Kenya’s next challenge is now to ensure that learners have access to digital literacy projects that provide not just conventional education, but holistic, skills-based, autonomous learning in order to meet its education vision and sustainable development goals by 2030.
yoruba: Ìpènijà tí ó kángun sí orílẹ̀-èdè Kenya báyìí ni láti rí i wí pé àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní oore-ọ̀fẹ́ sí àwọn iṣẹ́ àkànṣe ìkàwé ìgbàlódé tí kì í ṣe ẹ̀kọ́-ìwé nìkan ni yóò máa kọ́ni, sùgbọ́n àpapọ̀ ẹ̀kọ́ tí yóò tún máa kọ́ni lọ́gbọ́n àtiṣe lóríṣìiríṣìi, ìmọ̀ àtilèdádúró láti lè bá àfojúsùn wọn àti ìmúṣẹ ìlepa ìgbérò ìdàgbàsókè tí ó bá fi máa di ọdún 2030.

english: The struggle to end Nigeria's brutal SARS police unit continues
yoruba: Ìlàkàkà láti fi òpin sí òkúrorò SARS ẹ̀ka ilé-isẹ́ ọlọ́pàá ilẹ̀ Nàìjííríà ń tẹ̀síwájú.

english: Nigerian youth continue to protest throughout the country
yoruba: Àwọn ọ̀dọ́ Nàìjíríà ń tẹ̀síwájú ìfẹ̀hónúhàn jákèjádò orílèèdè náà

english: Posted 15 October 2020 14:40 GMT
yoruba: Àtẹ̀jáde ìtúmọ̀ 15 Ọ̀wàrà 2020

english: Read this post in Yorùbá, Français, Español
yoruba: Ka àtẹ̀jáde yìí ní Français, Español, English

english: Protesters gather to end SARS on October 13, 2020, in Ikeja, Lagos.
yoruba: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn kóra jọ láti fi òpin sí ikọ̀ SARS ní Ọjọ́ 13, Oṣù Òwàrà, Ọdún 2020, ní Ikeja, Èkó.

english: Photo by Nora Awolowo, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Nora Awolowo, s̩ís̩àmúlò pẹ̀lú ìyọ̀nda.

english: Over the last week, Nigerian youth have risen up in masses to wage war against a unit of the Nigeria Police Force known as The Special Anti-Robbery Squad (SARS), notorious for extrajudicial killings, extortion, kidnapping, and rape since the unit was created in 1992.
yoruba: Láti ọ̀sẹ̀ tó ti kọjá, àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjííríà ti gbéra sọ lọ́pọ̀ yanturu láti gbógun ti ẹ̀ka kan lábẹ Ilé-Iṣẹ́ Ọlọ́pàá Orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjííríà tí a mọ̀ sí Ikọ̀ Agbógunti Ìdigunjalè (SARS), èyí tí wó̩n gbajúgbajà fún ìṣekúpani, ìlọ́nilọ́wọ́gbà, ìjínigbé, ìfipábánilòpọ̀ láti ọdún 1992 tí wọ́n ti dáwo̩n sílẹ̀.

english: More than 100 people have reportedly been killed by SARS in past four to five years, according to Amnesty International.
yoruba: Ó lé ní o̩gó̩rùn-ún ènìyàn tí Ikọ̀ SARS ti ṣekú pa láti bí ọdún mẹ́rin sí márùn-ún sẹ́yìn gẹ́gẹ́ bí Amnesty International ṣe jábọ̀.

english: Nigerian youth — often the target of SARS — have, on several occasions, clamored for a total scrap of the unit, to no avail.
yoruba: Àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjííríà ­— tí ó máa ń jẹ́ àfojúsùn ikọ̀ SARS lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà — ti figbe ta láìmọye ìgbà pé kí wọn ó pa ẹ̀ka náà rẹ́ pátápátá ṣùgbọ́n wó̩n ko̩tí o̩gbó̩in si.

english: But this time, several recent arrests and killings in Lagos State sparked the zeal to make this a reality — after the SARS was disbanded about four times in four years — has driven mass action on the streets.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní báyìí, ìfipáńpẹ́-ọba-gbé àti ìṣekúpani tó ń peléke sí i lẹ́nu lọ́ọ́lọ́ yìí ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó ni ó tún ta àwọn ènìyàn jí láti rí i pé ó wá sí ìmúṣẹ —lẹ́yìn tí Ikọ̀ SARS ti kọ́kọ́ di tíkúkà ní ẹ̀ẹ̀mẹrin ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ láàárín ọdún mẹ́rin — ti fa ìwó̩de ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn nígboro.

english: READ MORE: ‘Lazy’ Nigerian youth mobilize #EndSARS protest from social media to the streets
yoruba: KÀ SÍWÁJÚ: ‘Ò̩lẹ’ ọ̀dọ́ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjííríà kó ìfẹ̀hónúhàn #EndSars (FI ÒPIN SÍ IKỌ̀ SARS) jọ láti orí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà títí dé àárín ìgboro.

english: This war against police brutality has also created a wave of awareness and generated a lot of conversations in the media space.
yoruba: Ìgbógunti ìwà òkúrorò àwọn ọlọ́pàá yìí tún di ohun tí gbogbo ènìyàn ń gbà bí ẹni gba igbá ọtí, ó sì tún di kókó ọ̀rọ̀ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìtàkùrọsọ lórí gbàgede ẹ̀rọ alátagbà

english: Protests have erupted in at least 12 of Nigeria’s 36 states, including Abuja, the federal capital, and Lagos, where protesters have blocked toll gates and airports within the state, hoping it makes an economic effect so elected leaders can acknowledge the protesters’ wishes in no time.
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀hónúhàn ti gbéra sọ ní ó kéré tán ìpínlẹ̀ méjìlá nínú ìpínlẹ̀ mé̩rìndínlógójì orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjííríà tí ó fi mọ́ Abuja, olú-ìlú orílẹ̀-èdè náà àti Èkọ́, níbi tí àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ti dí àwọn ẹnu ibodè asanwó-kí-a-tó-kọjá àti àwọn pápákọ̀ òfuurufú ní ìpínlẹ̀ náà, pẹ̀lú ìrètí àtimú kí ó fa ètò ọrọ̀ ajé sẹ́yìn kí àwọn adarí tí a yàn lè gbọ́ sí àwọn àfẹ̀hónúhàn lẹ́nu láifi àkókò ṣòfò.

english: Here are the protesters’ demands:
yoruba: Èyí ni àwọn ohun tí àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ń fẹ́:

english: Nigerians in the diaspora have also taken to the streets to show their displeasure with the notorious SARS unit which has, for years, committed crimes with impunity.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjííríà lẹ́yìn odi náà ti fọ́n sígboro láti fi àìdùnnú wọn hàn sí ikọ̀ ògbólógbo SARS yìí, tí ó ti ń hu oríṣiríṣi ìwa láabi láti àìmọye ọdún sẹ́yìn.

english: Protesters have gathered to denounce SARS in London, England, Dublin, Ireland, Ottawa and Toronto, Canada, Cologne, Germany, Moscow, Russia, Pretoria, South Africa, as well as Texas and Washington, DC, in the US.
yoruba: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ti kóra jọ ní London, England, Dublin, Ireland, Ottawa, àti Toronto, Canada, Cologne, Germany, Moscow, Russia, Pretoria, South Africa tí ó fi mọ́ Texas àti Washington, DC ní ilẹ̀ Amẹ́ríkà láti bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ikọ̀ SARS.

english: At least 10 protesters have been killed during the protests, according to Amnesty International.
yoruba: Ó kéré tan àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn mé̩wàá ni wọ́n ti ṣekú pa ní àsìkò ìfẹ̀hónúhàn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Amnesty International ṣe sọ.

english: Among those killed is Jimoh Isiaq, killed in Ogbomosho, Oyo State, and Ikechukwu Ilohamauzo, killed at the Surulere protest in Lagos, whose names both went viral on social media.
yoruba: Lára àwọn tí wọ́n pa ni Jimoh Isiaq, tí wọ́n pa ní ìlú Ògbómò̩s̩ó̩, Ìpínlẹ̀ Oyo, àti Ikechukwu Ilohamauzo tí wọn pa ní àsìkò ìfẹ̀hónúhàn Sùúrùlérè ní Èkó, tí orúkọ wọn gba orí àwọn ìkànnì ìbánidọ́rẹ̀ẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà kan.

english: Medical doctors have begun to accompany protesters in cases of emergency.
yoruba: Àwọn oníṣègùn òyìnbó tí ń kọ́wọ̀ọ́ rìn pẹ̀lú àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn tórí bí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ pàjáwìrì bá wáyé.

english: Protesters gather to denounce SARS, Monday, October 12, 2020, in Yaba, Lagos.
yoruba: Àwon afẹ̀hónúhàn kóra jọ láti bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ikọ̀ SARS ní Ọjọ́ kejìlá, Oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, Ọdún 2020 ní Yaba, Èkó.

english: Photo by Aremu Adeola Jr., used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Aremu Adeola Jr, s̩ís̩àmúlò pẹ̀lú ìyọ̀nda.

english: Inspector-General of Police Muhammad Adamu disbanded the unit a few days ago, but Nigerians are not convinced this will take effect as the previous disbandment of the unit never yielded positive results.
yoruba: Ọ̀gá àgbà Ọlọ́pàá nílẹ̀ Nàìjííríà Muhammad Adamu tú ikọ̀ náà ká ní bí ọjọ́ mélòó kan sẹ́yìn, ṣùgbọ́n ìgbésẹ̀ yìí kò tẹ́ àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjííríà lọ́rùn nítorí pé àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ tí wọ́n ti gbé ṣáájú nípa ikọ̀ náà kò so èso rere.

english: On Monday, President Muhammad Buhari of Nigeria assured citizens that the disbandment will be effective immediately and that the federal government will establish a presidential reform panel to look into police welfare and other critical areas, ensuring the demands of the masses be put into action.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ Ajé, Ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdè President Nàìjííríà Muhammad Buhari fi ọkàn àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè balẹ̀ pé ìgbésẹ̀ ì-tú-ikọ̀ náà ká yóò fẹsẹ̀ múlẹ̀ ní kíá, bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni ìgbìmọ̀ àtúndá ilé iṣẹ́ ààrẹ yóò rí sí ìgbáyégbádùn àwọn ọlọ́pàá àti àwọn nǹkan mìíràn tí ó tun ṣe pàtàkì, ó ń fi àrídájú hàn pé àwọn ìbéèrè àwọn ará ìlú yóò di mímú ṣe.

english: Some lawyers and human rights activists among youth activists have been working hard to release detained protesters.
yoruba: Àwọn amòfin tí wọ́n tún jẹ́ ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ tí ń ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára láti rí i pé wọ́n tú àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn tí wọ́n tì mólé sílẹ̀.

english: Protesters have made it clear that the fight to end SARS is not politically motivated, warning politicians, including members of opposition parties, not to hijack the protest for individual, party or political gains.
yoruba: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ti sọ ọ́ yanya pé ìjà fitafita láti fi òpin sí ikọ̀ SARS kò lọ́wọ́ òṣèlú nínú, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni wọ́n ṣe ìkìlọ̀ fún àwọn olóṣèlú tí ó fi mọ́ àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú alátakò láti má ṣe gbé ìfẹ̀hónúhàn ọ̀hún karí nítorí àtirí èrè nínú ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú tàbí ti òṣèlú gan pàá.

english: Protesters insist that there are no leaders in their movement and that every person who comes out to protest is a leader and follower alike.
yoruba: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn tákú pé kò sí adarí nínú ìfẹ̀hónúhàn wọn, wí pé ẹnikẹ́ni tí ó bá jáde láti wá fẹ̀hónú hàn jẹ́ adarí àti ọmọ ẹ̀yìn pèlú.

english: They insist that the presidency and/or the Inspector-General of Police address all grievances at once and not just a few selected individuals.
yoruba: Wọ́n takú pé kí ààrẹ àti/tàbí Ọ̀gá Àgbà Ilé iṣẹ́ Ọlọ́pàá dojú ọ̀rọ̀ kọ gbogbo àwọn tí inú ń bí ní ẹ̀ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo ni kì í ṣe pé kí wọn ó ṣa àwọn kan bá sọ̀rọ̀.

english: The question about who controls the police and SARS has not been adequately answered.
yoruba: Ìbéèrè lórí ẹni tí ó ń darí àwọn ọlọ́pàá àti ikọ̀ SARS kò tíì ní ìdáhùn tí ó jé̩ ìté̩wó̩gbà.

english: The constitution vested control of the police to the presidency under the supervision of the police chief.
yoruba: Ìwé òfin ilẹ̀ náà gbé agbára ìdárí ọlọ́pàá lé ààrẹ lọ́wọ́ lábẹ́ ìbòjútó ọ̀gá àgbà ilé iṣẹ́ ọlọ́pàá.

english: But that chain-of-command and control seems to have broken.
yoruba: Àmọ́ pé ẹ̀wọ̀n-àṣe àti ìdarí yẹn ti já.

english: To release protesters at Surulere, Lagos State, for example, it took calls from State Governor Babajide Sanwo-Olu, speaker of the federal house of representatives, Femi Gbajabiamila, and Desmond Elliot, Lagos State House of Assembly members representing Surulere and a few lawyers.
yoruba: Bí àpẹẹrẹ, láti jọ̀wọ́ àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ní Sùúrùlérè, ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó, èyí gba ìpè láti ọ̀dọ̀ Gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó Babájídé Sanwó-Olú, Abẹnugan ilẹ́ Ìgbìmọ̀ Aṣojúṣòfin Fẹ́mi Gbàjàbíàmílà, ọmọ ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó tí ó ń ṣojú ẹkùn Sùúrùlérè Desmond Elliot àti àwọn agbẹjórò díẹ̀.

english: On October 12, the governor of River State, Nyesom Wike, announced through a tweet that no protest — especially the #EndSARS protest — is allowed in his state.
yoruba: Ní Ọjọ́ kejìlá, Oṣù Òwàrà, Gómìnà Ìpínlẹ̀ Rivers Nyesom Wike, kéde láti orí túwíìtì kan pé kò sí ààyè fún ìfẹ̀hónúhàn kankan  — pàápàpá jùlọ ti #EndSARS protest — ní ìpínlẹ̀ òun.

english: That doesn't sit well with citizens.
yoruba: Èyí kò dùn mọ́ ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ọmọ ìlú nínú.

english: Several individuals responded through various platforms that the constitution which made him governor also gave citizens the fundamental right to protest.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ni wọ́n dá èsì padà lórí àwọn ìkànnì ẹ̀rọ àwùjọ pé ìwé òfin tí ó gbé gómínà dé orí ipò náà ni ó fún àwọn ọmọ ìlú ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti fi ẹ̀hónú hàn.

english: However, Wike recanted and addressed the protesters, expressing support for their cause.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, Wike yóhùn padà ó sì padà bá àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn sọ̀rọ̀, níbi tí ó ti fi àtìlẹ́yìn rẹ̀ hàn sí ìpè wọn

english: The protests continue in several parts of the country including River State. Protesters have promised not to back down until signs of compliance are seen by police and also the federal government.
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀hónúhàn yìí tẹ̀síwájú ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìlú ní orílẹ̀-èdè náà tí ó fi mọ́ ìpínlẹ̀ Rivers. Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ti ṣèlérí pé àwọn ò ní tẹ̀tì àyàfi bí àwọn bá rí ààmì ìyípadà ní ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ọlọ́pàá àti ọ̀dọ̀ ìjọba àpapọ̀.

english: On Tuesday, October 13, protesters reported on Twitter that at Iwo Road, Ibadan, members of the Nigerian Army were marching with protesters in solidarity.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ Ìṣẹ́gun, Ọjọ́ ke̩tàlá, Oṣù Òwàrà, àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ròyìn lórí Twitter pé ní Ìwó Road, Ìbàdàn, àwọn ọmọ ológun orí ilẹ̀ ń kọ́wọ̀ọ́rìn pẹ̀lú àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn pẹ̀lú ìsọ̀kan.

english: Also on October 14, Lagos State Governor Babajide Sanwo-Olu walked with protesters, reassuring them of the commitment of the government to end the menace.
yoruba: Bákan náà ní Ọjọ́ ke̩rìnlá, Oṣù Ò̩wàrà, Gómìnà Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó Babàjídé Sanwó-Olú kọ́wọ̀ọ́rìn pẹ̀lú àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn, níbi tí ó tún ti fi ìdánilójú àtìlẹyìn ìjọba hàn láti dé̩kun ohun aburú yìí.

english: The Lagos State Government says that ten victims of the July 4  Ijegun pipeline explosion have died due to severe and high degree burns suffered from the inferno.
yoruba: Ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó ní àwọn ènìyàn méwàá tó farakáásáá níbi ìsẹ̀lẹ̀ iná tó sẹlẹ̀ ní ọjọ́  kẹ̀rin oṣù Agẹmọ ní ìlú Ìjegun lóti dágbéré fún áyé bótijépé iná ohun ti jó wọn kọjá sísọ.

english: The Permanent Secretary, State Ministry of Health, Dr Titilayo Goncalves, who made this known to newsmen in Lagos,said that three of the victims died at the Lagos State University Teaching Hospital, Ikeja, while seven died at Gbagada General Hospital.
yoruba: Akọ̀wé ìjoba lórí ètò ìlera Dókítà Títílayò Goncalves tò bá àwọn Akọ̀ròyìn sọ̀rọ̀ ní mẹ́ta lára wọn lókú ní ilé ìwòsàn ẹ̀kọ́ṣẹ́ ètò ìlera Lagos State University Teaching Hospital Ikeja tí àwọn méje míì sì pàdánù ẹ̀mí ní Gbàgádà General Hospital Léèkó.

english: According to her, out of the 22 victims rescued by the Lagos State Ambulance Service, nine were taken to LASUTH, 12 to Trauma and Burns Unit of Gbagada General Hospital and one to Alimosho General Hospital.
yoruba: Nínú ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀, ó ní àwọn ènìyàn méjìlélógún tí wọ́n fi Ọkọ̀ pàjáwìrì gbé níbi ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ọ̀hún ni wọ́n gbé ènìyàn mẹ́sàn án sí LASUTH, tí méjìlá sì wà ní ẹka ìjàmbá iná Gbàgádà General Hospital tí ẹ̣nìkan sì wà ni Àlímòṣọ́ General Hospital.

english: She also said that they are doing everything possible to ensure that no other life is lost and from reports received, they are responding to treatment.
yoruba: Dókítà Titilayo ní gbogbo ìgbìyànjú làwọn wa láti máse pàdánù ẹ̀mí Kankan mọ́. Bákanáà lóní ara àwọn tó kù ti ń yá.

english: Greece's new Prime Minister, MrKyriakos Mitsotakis has said that he would not fail to honour the hopes of the Greek people after New Democracy's landslide victory.
yoruba: Ààrẹ tintun orílẹ̀ èdè Greece’s, Mrkyriakos Mitsotakis ti ní òun ò ní já àwọn ará ìlú ní tàn-án mọ̀n lẹ́hìn tí Ìjọba ti bọ́si lọ́wọ́.

english: Mr. Mitsotakis emerged the winner of the election with several votes.
yoruba: Mr Mitsotakis tófi ẹ̀yìn akegbẹ́ jọnlẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àbájáde egbelemùkú ìbò.

english: This Prime minister said his government will be a peaceful one.
yoruba: Prime minister yìí tún ní òun yóò ṣe ìjọba àlááfíà lórí gbogbo ará ìlú.

english: He also promised to renegotiate a deal with Greece's creditors that would allow more money to be reinvested in the country.
yoruba: Bákannáà lótún ṣe ìlérí láti sè ìpàdé pẹ̀lú àwọn Olókòwò Greece láti leè fàyè gba ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ owó síi ìlú.

english: President Muhammadu Buhari returned to Abuja on Monday after attending the 12th Extraordinary Summit of the African Union in Niamey, Niger Republic.
yoruba: Ààrẹ Mohammedu Buhari ti padá sí Àbújá lọ́jọ́ ajé lẹ́hìn ìpàdè ẹlẹ́ẹ̀kejìlá àpèjọ àrà ọ̀tọ̀ pẹ̀lú Àjo Africa Union ní Niamey Niger Republic.

english: The News Agency of Nigeria reports that the presidential aircraft conveying the President and some members of his entourage landed at àthe Presidential Wing of the Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport Abuja at about 1:25 p.m.
yoruba: Àjọ Akọ̀ròyìn News Agency of Nigeria jábọ̀ pé ọkọ̀ òfurufú tó gbé Ààrẹ àti àwọn tí wọ́n jọ kọ́ọ̀wọ̀rìn balè igun pápákọ̀ Nnamdi Azikwe International Airport Abuja ní aago kan kọjá ìṣẹ́jú mẹ́ẹ̀dógún.

english: The president signed the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) agreement, making Nigeria the 53rd state in the continent to append its signature to the document.
yoruba: Ààrẹ fọwọ́sí ìwé àdéhùn pẹ̀lú AfCFTA gẹ́gẹ́ bí Ààre ketàlélọ́gọ́ta tí yóò tí owọ́ bọ ìwé yìí lágbàáyé.

english: The President had delayed signing the agreement, which entered into force on May 30, 2019.
yoruba: Ààre dá ìwé yí dúró de osú karùn-ún ọdún 2019.

english: The delay was to give room for extensive consultations with stakeholders, culminating in the submission of the report by the presidential committee, to assess the impact and readiness of Nigeria to join the free trade area.
yoruba: Ìdádúró tí wọ́n fi àyè gbà àwọn Alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀, Onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ láti jábọ̀ ìwádìí wọn bí Nigeria se gbaradì láti darapọ̀ mọ́ wọn.

english: The advocacy for gender balance and equal opportunity is not meant to engender rivalry between men and women; rather it is aimed at ensuring that both women and men are given equal opportunities in the various sphere of our national life.
yoruba: Ìpolongo àti ìkéde lórí ẹ̀tò láàrín àwọ̀n ọkùnrin sí Obìrinbi kìí ṣe fún ìfi igagbága bíkòsepé kí takọ tabo ilẹ̀ yìí le kópa nínú ìlọsíwájú orílẹ̀ èdè wa.

english: A former Minister of Industry, Dr. Nike Akande made the clarification in Lagos at an event organized by the State Government to mark this year’s International Women’s Day, IDW.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ yìí ni mínísítà fún ètò iṣé dokita Nike Akande sọ níbi ètò kan tí Ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀ Èkò gbé kalẹ̀ láti sàmì àyájọ́ Àwọn Obìnrin lágbàáyé [IDW].

english: She noted that the Nigeria of our dreams is a country led by the best of our people and a place where there is justice, fair play and equality.
yoruba: Ó fi kún ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ pé ìwòye ọjọ́ iwájú Orílẹ̀ èdè yìí ni ìṣèjọba tí àwọn tó dántọ́ ṣe àkóso rẹ̀ àti ibi tí ètò ìdájọ́, Ìsọ̀kan àti Orí ò ju orí wà.

english: In a message, Governor of Lagos, Mr Akinwunmi Ambode, who was represented by the Commissioner for Youths and Social Development, Agboola Dabiri acknowledged that women had been contributing immensely to the political and economic growth of the state and advised those who are mothers and guardians to encourage the youths, particularly girls to have good behaviour so as to be good leaders tomorrow.
yoruba: Nínú Ọ̀rọ́ tí Gómìnà Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Akíwùnmí Ambode tí Kómísóná fún ọ̀rọ̀ àwọn Ọ̀dọ́ àti Ìdàgbàsókè Àwùjọ, Agboọlá Dábírí tó sojú fún, ni tí a bá wo inú agbo òsèlú, ipa ribiribi làwọn Obìrin ńkó pèlu ètò ọrọ Ajé Ìpínlè,   bákan náà lótún rọ àwọn Òbí àti Alágbàtọ́ láti ma gba àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ĺámọ̀ràn pàápàá àwọn Ọ̀dómọbìnrin láti ni ìwà ọmọlúwàbí kí wọ́n lè jẹ́ aṣíwájú rere lẹ́yìn ọ̀la.

english: A member of Lagos State Assembly representing Eti-Osa Constituency Two, Mr. Gbolahan Yishawu has saluted workers for their immense contribution to the nation’s building.
yoruba: Asojú ni ilé Ìgbìmọ̀ asòfin tó ń sojú ekùn Etì ọ̀sà kejì, Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Gbóláhàn Yishawu ti gbóríyìn fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ fún àtìlẹyìn wọn láti gbé Orílẹ̀ èdè yìí ga.

english: Mr. Yishawu in his May Day message to congratulate the Nigerian workers and their efforts in ensuring progress and development in their various working place commended the courage of the Nigerian Labour Congress and Trade Union Congress for their quest to ensure increase in workers minimum wage.
yoruba: Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Yishawu nínú ìwé Àpilẹ̀ko tó fi kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ tó sì dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ Àjo Àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àjo tó n mú ojútó Ayédáadé Òṣìṣẹ́ àti Àjo Olókòwò bí wọ́n ṣe ja Àjàyè lórí èkúnwó owó oṣù àwọn òṣìṣẹ́.
